name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Good morning. My apologies for the slight delay. I think some people had difficulty with traffic this morning, so thank you for your patience. The sitting is now open. (The sitting opened at 9.06) Before we move to the first item on the agenda, there is a point of order from Mr Corbett.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: – Madam President, under Rule 162(3) and (6), Parliament has decided that this debate we are about to start on Brexit will only have a round of speakers from the leaders of each of the political groups. That has a consequence, Madam President. There will be three British voices in that debate, each and every one of them from those who support Brexit. Parliament will not hear a single British voice from those who oppose Brexit, which according to the latest opinion polls actually represents the majority view of the British population. (Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you, Mr Corbett. Your point is noted. It was a decision of the political groups to have this format. I’m in the hands of the decision of the political groups, but I think your point is well taken by the plenary.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the UK’s withdrawal from the European Union 2018/2958(RSP)).

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, Chief Negotiator Barnier, ladies and gentlemen, the European Council endorsed the agreement of the withdrawal of the UK from the EU and Euratom. The European Council then invited the Commission, the European Parliament and the Council to take the necessary steps to ensure that the agreement can enter into force on 30 March 2019. The European Council also approved the political declaration setting out the framework for the future relationship between the EU and the UK. On that occasion, the Union’s determination to have as close as possible a partnership with the UK in the future was restated in line with that declaration. This outcome would not have been possible without the commitment and the determination of Mr Barnier and his team, to which the European Council paid tribute. No less important was the sense of unity, shared purpose and responsibility amongst the EU’s 27 Member States, as well as amongst the EU institutions. On this particular occasion, I should like to express my appreciation for the constant involvement and timely contribution of the Brexit Steering Group and, more broadly, the European Parliament. In the coming months we will have to secure the conclusion of the withdrawal agreement. The Council is doing its utmost to adopt its decision on signature in the coming weeks, which should allow the EP to complete its consent procedure in good time, before the end of March 2019.

name: Michel BARNIER
text: Chief Brexit Negotiator. Madam President, Madam Secretary of State, ladies and gentlemen, good morning to each and every one of you. I thank you for giving me the opportunity to speak on behalf of the European Commission and apologise to President Jean-Claude Juncker, who is currently attending the G20 summit.  Madam President, we are at an important and serious moment, seventeen months after the start of the negotiations, that I have had the honour and that I have the honour of leading under the authority and with the confidence of President Jean-Claude Juncker and with the support of the whole European Commission.  On Sunday, as you pointed out, Madam Secretary of State, the European Council approved our draft withdrawal agreement. He also endorsed the political declaration that sets the framework for our future relationship. At this stage, I would like to thank the European Council, its President, Donald Tusk, all its teams, but also the successive presidents with whom I have worked and worked well, the Austrian Presidency today, but also Bulgaria, Estonia and Malta. Then we will continue with Romania in the coming months. Ladies and gentlemen, the time for negotiations on the withdrawal agreement and the political declaration is over. Now is the time for ratification by the British Parliament, by your Parliament and by the Council.  Given the difficult circumstances of this negotiation and the extreme complexity of all the subjects of this British withdrawal, the agreement that is on the table - the draft orderly withdrawal and the political declaration - is the only one and the best possible.  We have succeeded in this first major step together and, on the European side, thanks to the very strong unity of the 27 Member States and all the institutions between them.  In particular, Madam President, the withdrawal agreement and this political declaration owe much to your four resolutions and the careful vigilance you have shown since the beginning of this negotiation, of course, to preserve the rights of the citizens you represent - it was your priority, it was my priority - to preserve the interests of the European Union, the integrity of the single market and the indivisibility of the four freedoms , and the Union's decision-making autonomy. We co-constructed these two documents together throughout the process. Madam President, through you, I also want to thank President Tajani and allow me to say a more personal word to Guy Verhofstadt, coordinator of your Brexit assembly, and to each and every member of the Brexit steering group, Danuta Hunner, Elmar Brok, Roberto Gualtieri, Gabriele Zimmer and Philippe Lamberts who followed with all their teams , which I thank, the day-to-day negotiations within this steering group. I would also like to thank the group chairs, the committee chairs and Cecilia Wikstrom, knowing that we are not at the end of a long road that will remain difficult. The agreement reached on Sunday is also the result of a method that we have decided together and with you. We put things in order, starting - as it made sense - with negotiating the withdrawal agreement, an orderly withdrawal, before discussing the framework of our future relationship with the United Kingdom. We have insisted on addressing upstream some of the issues that were and are still a priority for your Parliament, namely the rights of citizens, peace and stability in Ireland, and the financial settlement. Ladies and gentlemen, from the outset, we have worked with transparency, that is, with confidence, and we will continue.  This method allowed us to explain the issues of each subject, to show what was possible and what was not, given the fundamental principles of our Union.  From the beginning, we have explained how we can and should respect our principles and, at the same time, take into account the red lines officially indicated by the United Kingdom. Finally, we found common ground. In a nutshell, the framework we have set has given stability and predictability to this negotiation. No one can be objectively surprised by the content of our agreement.  Ladies and gentlemen, it may be worth pointing out at this stage that the European Union did not want Brexit. To date, no one else has been able to show me the added value of Brexit, but we respect the democratic and sovereign vote of the British citizens and so, as the British Government has requested, have implemented this process for an orderly exit. Simply, the two documents approved on Sunday help to limit the negative consequences of Brexit on both sides but also, in particular, 27 EU Member States.  The withdrawal agreement provides legal certainty to all people, businesses and regions concerned about the consequences of the British decision to leave the European Union: of course, European citizens, 4 and a half million people living in the UK and British citizens living in one of the EU countries; the inhabitants and businesses of Ireland and Northern Ireland, Madam President, who participate in all the human, social and economic dimensions of North-South cooperation. The last resort solution on which we have agreed to avoid the return of a physical border in Ireland while protecting the single market is an integral part of the withdrawal agreement. Without this solution for Ireland, there is no withdrawal agreement. Communities then, universities and companies that carry out so many projects funded by European policies and budgets, including with UK partners, universities, extremely dynamic laboratories in the UK. Farmers who benefit from the common agricultural policy and who legitimately wanted to protect their intellectual property rights, and much more than that, through geographical indications. And then, all those whose personal data were exchanged with uk-based organizations or companies. These are the people and sectors for which we had a duty to restore security where Brexit has created insecurity. That is the purpose of this very dense withdrawal agreement, I agree, because it is a legal treaty, precise and comprehensive.  As for the political declaration, it sets the framework in which we will, as soon as possible, negotiate our future relationship.  Ladies and gentlemen, in this negotiation the European Union will continue to defend its interests and apply exactly the same principles.  In this negotiation which is about to begin, the Union will adopt, as will your negotiator, the same attitude. There will never be and there has never been aggression. There will never be and there has never been a spirit of revenge. There will never be and there has never been any kind of punishment on my part. We will continue to work with the United Kingdom, not against it, to build this future partnership and we will continue to work with the respect due to a great country that will remain our friend, partner and ally.  The truth about this future relationship is that, given the British decision to leave the European Union and the single market, this cannot be the status quo in the future. This cannot be "business as usual" and our duty is to say so, especially to companies, which must prepare. But our mutual interest is to build an ambitious partnership on goods, services, digital, mobility, transport, public procurement, energy, internal security - of course - for the stability of our continent, foreign policy with this country that will remain active in the UN Security Council, defence and many other areas.  The more ambitious this partnership is, the more attentive and demanding we will be on the framework of the conditions of competition between us. In total, if we make this political statement in all these dimensions, let me tell you - and I say if we are making this political statement in all these dimensions - the partnership with the United Kingdom will be unprecedented in the scope and number of topics of cooperation.  As President Juncker has wanted and as the Member States and your Parliament have wished, we will prepare and be ready to launch this negotiation on the future relationship, once the United Kingdom becomes a third country.  But before that, Madam President, there is obviously a decisive step, that of ratifying our withdrawal agreement. Now is the time for everyone to take responsibility. In the coming weeks, British parliamentarians will have to vote on this withdrawal agreement and the text of the political declaration and this vote commits the future of their country. We must respect - and I will respect - this debate and this time of parliamentary and democratic debate in the United Kingdom. For our part, we must leave this time of ratification to the European Parliament, which has been and will remain closely associated with each stage of this negotiation, and which will have the final say. Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your trust and attention.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: (Parliament's Brexit coordinator) on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to welcome the withdrawal agreement and the political declaration. I think that we can say easily today that both have been built around the principles of the European Union – that means the integrity of the Single Market, that means the four freedoms which underpin that Single Market and that means the ability, the capacity of the European Union to decide in an autonomous way. But I have to tell you, and I think it’s important in these debates, that also two other elements have been taken into account. The first are naturally the positions – maybe I have to say the red lines – of the UK Government following the decision to end the membership of the European Union. Then, a second important point that underpins this agreement or these agreements, and that is something often underplayed and not fully understood, is the 1998 Good Friday Agreement, though the European Union is in fact not a direct party in this. The 1998 Agreement was only possible among EU Member States, between EU Member States, and it shows, in my opinion, that the European Union is about that, about reconciliation, about the end of violence, about peace. The result of all this is the withdrawal agreement, and I think the only and best agreement possible, considering these three elements that I have just described. In achieving this, I would like to thank, naturally, and congratulate – it’s not the first time that I’m doing this – Michel Barnier personally. He has done a tremendous job in close cooperation with the European Parliament and with the Brexit Steering Group, and this also gives me the possibility to congratulate all the members of the Brexit Steering Group for the good cooperation beyond the lines of the political parties. I think that it worked very well. Now, the result, Michel, is an agreement that, in my opinion, does three things. The first is to minimise the disruption for both sides, in particular for the economy, and to allow for an orderly withdrawal and allow for a timeframe between two and four years to conclude the negotiations on the future relationship. The second result is to avoid a hard border on the island of Ireland, to safeguard the Good Friday Agreement and to secure peace. Then the third thing – and I think this was the first priority of the European Parliament – is to safeguard the rights of all citizens. Here the European Parliament has, with the help and with the support of our negotiators, significantly improved the agreement and the text. Moreover, we are also committed – and I want to tell you this today – to ensuring that, before we start the consent procedure in the European Parliament, we receive from our British counterparts the necessary guarantees that all these citizens’ rights will be fully implemented. I believe that this framework – withdrawal agreement and political declaration – provides for the possibility to establish in the future a really close relationship between the European Union and the United Kingdom and the basis, therefore, as you have seen in the agreement, in the political declaration, is an association agreement, as the European Parliament has proposed from day one. Why an association agreement, on which also the British Government has agreed? Well, it will be applicable, once concluded, in a provisional way after approval at the European level. Secondly, it will be ratified in one round of ratification by the Member States, so as to avoid – if I may say so – the complexity of, for example, our relationship with Switzerland, which is based not on one association agreement, but on a patchwork of agreements. The Brexit Steering Group, along with the whole European Parliament, will further scrutinise the deal, the withdrawal agreement and the political declaration on the future relationship, as part of the consent procedure.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: (Exclamations by certain members of Parliament) Colleagues, I am in the Chair, so I will call time, with due respect. Thank you for your guidance, but you will respect the Chair please.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Parliament will, in this respect, look very carefully into how the so—called Joint Committee will work. We want to ensure that the decisions that are taken by the Joint Committee are legitimate and, where necessary, also require the approval of the Parliament. I hope that, before we start the consent procedure, we can have an agreement with the Council. Let’s be clear that there will be no winners in this. I think that the departure of the UK from the Union is a failure for everybody – for the UK and for the EU. Last Sunday – we have to tell our colleagues this – was a sad day for both. So let us make the best of it in the knowledge that in the near future there will be a new generation in Britain who will – and I’m pretty sure about this – decide to come back into the great political European family.  (Applause)

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Brexit is a bad thing for us in the European Union and for Britain – more for Britain because of its different size than for us, but also for us. That is why Sunday was a sad day, as Guy Verhofstadt – whom I thank for the cooperation – correctly analysed. But the negotiating skills of Michel Barnier and his team, his patience and information policy within the European Union have succeeded in getting the best deal possible.  I have to say that in Britain the government is divided, the ruling party is divided, the opposition is divided, the country is divided. This European Union, which is supposed to be at the end, was in agreement with 27 countries, with the Council, the Commission and Parliament, and Parliament also agreed. This European Union has a great chance for the future; it has proved this in these Brexit negotiations. We must see that we minimise this damage to the United Kingdom, as was made clear once again yesterday by the Bank of England's statement: there will be greater losses in growth in the UK as a result of Brexit than the financial damage of 2008. That is the Bank of England's statement yesterday. Mr Farage, who is Mr Trump's speechwriter, can explain what he wants to continue lying to his country. That will not change the facts. We must realise, however, that this means – and I believe that the European Parliament supports this – that there is no further negotiations. It's this deal and no other. It is not possible again, not according to the method "reject again, then we negotiate again, and then there is a new deal". This is an agreement that stands, it has to be taken, it has been negotiated for a long time. For this reason, it must be clear that the Withdrawal Treaty is a condition for a transitional arrangement. I have the impression that this is not clear to some people in the United Kingdom. If the Withdrawal Treaty does not come, there is no transitional arrangement. The break will be thunderous – for both sides. We must realise that this Treaty must also make it clear that it is a difficult and risky matter for Remainers to now think that they will reject this Treaty and perhaps get something else, including a referendum, before 29 March. I think this is a very dangerous undertaking. This deal should be taken for security reasons to minimize the damage. That is why I am appealing to both sides in the UK in this game. We have noted that this treaty will ensure the transitional arrangements of this Treaty, that the rights of citizens who have relied on the existence of the European Union from both sides in their personal life planning, that there will be no hard border with catastrophic human and economic consequences between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland, and that we have agreed on a backstop in doing so. , which, while the transitional period is in progress, does not enter into force at all, and that we then negotiate the future treaty without it coming into force. The aim of the backstop is not to put it into effect. This must be clear, and that is why it must not be abused, even in the discussions in the United Kingdom.  I believe that, in order to minimise the damage, we must conduct future relations in the common interest with great constructive awareness of a solution. Britain does not want a customs union because they want to make their own trade deals. They do not want to be members of the internal market because they do not want to fulfil the four freedoms. But everything that is possible after that should be made possible. That is why we should be making a free trade agreement that is very broad. Theresa May was right when she said in the spring that the more we are similar in our standards, the more level playing field we have, the more market access there is. This should be seen in this context in order to minimise the damage in the way possible. However, we should make it clear that this partnership agreement, which was initiated by the European Parliament and which is now included in the agreement – we have also mentioned it – should include this trade agreement to a large extent, but also issues of internal and external security. It is in the interests of both parties that we make agreements in the fight against terrorism, that we have a British involvement in a certain possible sense, including in the common security and defence policy. Both sides want to do so. To this end, this Withdrawal Treaty sets the appropriate framework conditions for negotiating this in another treaty in order to ensure the security of our peoples. This also applies to other areas, such as research, when I see the situation of English universities and how much they want to be in the research programme. Let me make one final comment: Mr Farage writes Mr Trump's speeches, and Mr Trump said the day before yesterday that he would not even do this withdrawal agreement because he does not want to negotiate with Britain in this way. Mr. Trump wants all European countries to be divided, isolated, so that he can take them individually, beat them individually, and finish them. This Trump speech is the best rationale for the future need ingesantiated European Union so that our peoples can join forces against the Trumps and Putins and Xi. can defend. We will not let that be destroyed by Mr Farage's speeches he writes for Mr Trump.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, after long and difficult negotiations, the agreement reached on Sunday sets the basis for an orderly withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union, and we are ready to ratify it.  On behalf of the S&D Group, I would like to thank Michel Barnier for the outstanding work he and his team have done in dealing with this historic challenge. At the same time, I cannot hide my profound sadness about the UK’s choice to leave the Union. Our Group respects this decision, but we deeply regret it. We consider it an historic mistake. In our eyes, it will always be a lose—lose situation. Despite the disappointment and the frustration, the EU – and all of us – have acted, since the very beginning of the process, with responsibility and respect. We have worked tirelessly for more than two years to protect those most affected by the decision and to alleviate its worst possible consequences. This was achieved thanks to the guidance of our lead negotiators and thanks to the unity within, and between, the EU institutions. I would also like to thank Guy Verhofstadt and all the members of the Brexit Steering Group. We have been – and we shall be – always united. The EU has been responsible towards the UK by providing the basis to deliver an orderly withdrawal without any feelings of revenge or resentment. We have also been responsible towards ourselves and our citizens not to endanger the European project and the integrity of our Union. This sense of responsibility shall continue to guide us going forward.  One thing must be clear, though. There is no alternative deal to the one agreed on Sunday. Considering the United Kingdom’s red lines, this is the best, and the only possible, agreement. It is a deal that protects citizens’ rights, safeguards the integrity of the single market and the customs union and, crucially, prevents a hard border on the island of Ireland, respecting the Good Friday Agreement in all its parts. We know that on citizens’ rights, which have been our priority from the start, our work is far from being finished and we will remain vigilant with respect to the implementation of this part of the agreement. We will never allow EU citizens to fall victim to the same disgraceful hostile—environment policies that saw members of the Windrush generation wrongly deported. The political declaration accompanying the withdrawal agreement establishes the framework and basis for an ambitious, broad and deep partnership. This unprecedented partnership, which should take the form of an association agreement, shall fully respect the integrity of the single market and the autonomy of our legal order. We also welcome all the interpretative declarations adopted by the Council and consider them legally binding, including with regard to Gibraltar. On the future relationship, the UK has made its red lines clear throughout the process – just as we have – and we respect this. In the negotiations we have shown a high degree of flexibility and we have stretched the deal as much as we could in order to take into account the position and the constraints of the United Kingdom. We have always said – and we repeat it now – that if the UK changes its mind our arms are, and will remain, open. But insofar as you want to leave the single market and no longer apply the principle of free movement of persons, this is the only possible way to leave the European Union in an orderly manner, avoiding the severe disruption of a no—deal scenario. There is no other deal that could respect such limits without compromising or endangering our European project. This Parliament is the very symbol of our common project and of the links between countries and people. This is why we will continue to play a responsible and proactive role in safeguarding the integrity of the Union and ensuring a positive future relationship with the United Kingdom. (Applause)

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, (inaudible) ... lot of experts on domestic British policy these days. Look, Brexit was always about much more than the economy. In a way, because the European Union strayed so far into many other areas, into our national lives, it is why the British people voted for Brexit. They were increasingly unhappy with this tendency. You say you didn’t want Brexit, but you did nothing to avoid it. But of course the economic aspects are central. A bad deal for Britain or no deal will have repercussions in many European countries as well as Britain. Much time seems to be spent here on predicting events in London and the consequences of Brexit for Britain. Perhaps we should look at the impact of a bad deal or a sour relationship on the European Union. Certainly, the British government entered into negotiations in a spirit of goodwill, aiming for a positive future partnership. There’s been astonishment in Britain over the legalistic inflexibility that has been shown quite often. But we all know that the EU will bend or break any of its own rules when it suits it, and instead of defending the long-term interests of EU countries, it seems to have chosen to pursue a narrow ideological course defending a particular view of the EU project, which is increasingly repudiated by citizens across Europe; it may appeal to the leaders of a couple of the larger countries in the European Union. Instead of listening to citizens, your answer to everything is just more Europe. And by the way, I think a lot of people have been very cross in Britain about the discourteous way in which our Prime Minister seems often to have been treated. Because of your insistence on a bizarre sequencing arrangement, you’ve wasted two years when you could already have made progress on a free trade agreement. All other issues would then have fallen into place – it wasn’t necessary to do it in the way you did. This makes it all the more important to move quickly into negotiating our future relationship and reaching rapid but correct conclusions, but we need some reassurance and flexibility – indeed, guarantees – from the EU over concerns that have been expressed. We need an atmosphere of trust and goodwill from your side if we are to have that future positive, stable relationship that is surely the least that all our citizens demand. (Applause)

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, dear colleagues, at the EU Council last Sunday, many asked me if I felt sad. Actually rather than sadness, I felt gratitude first to Michel Barnier and his outstanding team. Not only did they negotiate the agreement, keeping in mind the common interests of the EU without ever losing their nerve, they did so – and that is one of Michel’s defining qualities – involving the Council and Parliament on an equal footing, keeping the EU team together in more than one way. Of course, this agreement is not perfect; as far as we Greens/EFA are concerned, we would have liked to see something more than non-regression clauses on social and environmental matters as a condition for the UK staying in the customs union, and the political declaration should, again, have been more explicit about conditioning our future relationship on the UK not becoming a tax haven or a money laundering country. The countdown has to be tough on these issues as we move forward. I also felt relieved: relieved that, after 18 months of very hard work, an agreement could be found. Had that not been the case, the worst-case scenario of the UK crashing out of the European Union would have become the likeliest, causing major damage not just to business but above all to people. Relief that the EU could reach this agreement with the UK without compromising on its integrity. Relief that the British government had finally come to terms with reality. The ball is now clearly in the UK’s court. The Prime Minister has come to terms with reality, but it remains to be seen whether she will find a majority supporting the deal in the House of Commons. To the dissatisfied Brexiteers I will say this: if a negotiated Brexit is what you want and unless you would also consider keeping the country inside the single market, no other deal is available. Whoever negotiates on behalf of the UK will face the same legal constraints as Theresa May did, and I hope no one of you is seriously considering leaving without an agreement. Because if the UK did that, it would be in breach of the Good Friday Agreement, because at once a border would be re-erected in Ireland. It would also be in breach of its financial commitments taken under the EU Treaties during its membership period, because leaving a club, my friends, does not free you from paying your outstanding debt. In other terms, crash Brexit would make the UK a rogue state, a country whose signature with any other partner would amount to just nothing. The real choice, therefore, is only between Brexit under the terms negotiated, and no Brexit at all. That choice will have such an impact on the future of the country that as a Democrat I would find it normal that we would ask the people, especially as the major parties seem to be very divided on the issue. (Applause) I will agree with remainers that your country finds itself in a less enviable position now than it was as a Member State, because indeed, European Union is a boost to sovereignty. In this world, if we want to have impact, we need to act together. And I think many British citizens realise that. Are they a majority? We don’t know. Can we find a way to ask them? If there is one, it is very narrow. (Applause) But I’m certain, though, that if the UK wants to renounce its intention to leave, we should embrace it back with pleasure. Equally – and that is my final word, Madam President – I think it would be a utterly, utterly irresponsible to end up with the UK crashing out of the European Union, either voluntarily or inadvertently. (Applause)

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her At its meeting last weekend, the Council approved the divorce agreement negotiated between the EU and the UK. And yet, at this moment, no one can say whether it makes a regulated Brexit more likely. It is therefore right for the EU and the Member States to prepare for the worst case scenario: a no-deal situation. Our participation as a group in the Brexit Steering Group and also our participation in Parliament's very first resolution last year – April 2017 – was not taken for granted from the outset. The decision that we support this platform, that we as a left-wing group should join the work of the Brexit Steering Group, was the right one. In this context, I would also like to say that cooperation with Michel Barnier has set standards for future cooperation between the institutions in the European Union. Even now, however, it must be made clear that the divorce agreement does not make us cheer. We are concerned that, particularly with regard to citizens' rights and northern Ireland, a number of our demands are not so entrenched that they could actually provide sufficient legal certainty for those affected by Brexit. What is not watertight in the Withdrawal Agreement cannot be remedied by declarations of intent. We breathe a sigh of relief because the Withdrawal Agreement, the Withdrawal Agreement, the Divorce Agreement, the Backstop, the Emergency Solution, were agreed to avoid a horror scenario in Ireland. However, the backstop does not do what was promised in the Joined Report of December last year: the border that divides Ireland will become harder, the cross-border economy will be affected, rights enshrined in the Good Friday Agreement will be minimised.  We are also concerned about how Theresa May is seeking the votes of doubters, critics from her camp for the Withdrawal Agreement, the divorce agreement. It now assures them that it will stop migrants from EU member states coming to Britain. It seems that the British Government – and with it not only the government, but also some of the colleagues who are sitting over here – has not yet understood what the essence of European citizenship is. They forget that they also deprive their own citizens of rights, and they raise the well-founded suspicion that EU citizens who want to live, work, study in the UK after Brexit, be discriminated against and discriminated against against people from other countries in the world.  At the weekend, the Heads of Government assured – and this has also been mentioned here several times here today – that the UK and the EU want to pursue the closest possible partnership after the separation. We support that. But if these are not just empty words, there is still a lot of work to be done on both sides. As the European Parliament, therefore – and here I fully agree with Guy Verhofstadt – we should continue to be committed, above all, to the interests of the citizens of Great Britain, but also within the European Union. We are also committed to the interests of UK citizens within the EU. I would also like to make that very clear once again. We will continue to put that in the foreground, as will the question of Northern Ireland.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, I’m in no doubt that this withdrawal agreement is a good deal. It’s a good deal because it involves large transfers of money. It’s a good deal because it maintains free movement of people. It’s a good deal because it keeps Britain in the customs union and stuck with the EU’s rulebook. And crucially, the key point, as Mr Barnier said this morning: there is the backstop, which means of course the United Kingdom can be held effectively as a hostage for many years to come. It’s a good deal for the European Union; for the UK, I think it’s probably the worst deal in history. Something, Mr Brok, that President Trump has noticed – and, by the way, he is a great respecter of the great nation states of Europe, and certainly no enemy of any single one of them. No, Mr Barnier, I have to say I wish you were on our side really, because it’s game, set and match to you. You probably can’t even believe your luck that you came up against a British Prime Minister who met every single demand of yours whilst at the same time trying to deceive the British public, and you took it to the big summit on Sunday, and in 38 minutes it was all agreed, done and dusted, and off to lunch. Well, I have to say, we will be leaving on 29 March next year, but any illusion at home that we’re going to be an independent country, I’m afraid, has been shattered. And before the ink was even dry last Sunday, President Macron of France stood up and decided to start to threaten us. Now, I understand the French do catch 90% of the haddock in the west of the English Channel and we get 10; I understand their interests. But I fear that we’re very much now open and at your mercy over the course of the next few years, and the truth of it is, in the political declaration, you haven’t got to give us anything. You don’t need to give us a thing, and that is why this is going to fail in Parliament, and probably fail by a very big margin. Now, Mr Barnier, you say this is the only possible deal. But this deal isn’t going to be accepted. So perhaps we all need to grow up and recognise that there is a strong chance now of the UK leaving on 29 March with a WTO no deal. We need a negotiated deal, to deal with sensible border issues. I wonder, Mr Barnier, are you prepared for that? Because you seemed this morning to assume that the British Parliament is going to ratify this. It isn’t. (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, the British people decided two years ago to leave the European Union. You have to respect your sovereign decision.  For the Europe of Nations and Freedoms group, which I represent today, respect for the sovereignty of each nation is a fundamental principle. It is shocking in this regard that a request to challenge Brexit has been lodged in the Court of Justice of the Union, which will rule on 4 December. In my view, no court has jurisdiction to question the effects of a referendum. In France, the Constitutional Council has understood this and refuses to control the referendums. I very much hope that the Court of Justice of the Union will take the same position. If it were to interpret Article 50 of the Treaty on the European Union in a way that was unfavourable to Brexit, it would have to resist. Sovereignty is not a set of powers that can be tied up by treaties or abandoned to the subjectivity of judges. It is a metajural power that allows each nation to freely decide its destiny.  Long live the British people. Long live Brexit.

name: James CARVER
text: – Madam President, last week Angela Merkel said, and I quote, ‘what’s been important to us it that the UK cannot decide unilaterally when the customs union ends but rather has to define that timeframe jointly with the EU.’ The European institutions took control in 1973 and, ironically, continue that control through this 2018 Brexit betrayal deal. This deal means that we remain a nation of supplicants. We’ve lost the freedom teasingly dangled before us through the 2016 referendum results, when a British establishment and political class were rudely reminded that the British people want to take back their sovereign control. Ataturk’s wise words now seem more appropriate than ever when he said ‘sovereignty is not given, it is taken’. This is a terrible deal: bad because the EU continues to hold my country over a barrel and the British politicians who sign up to it need to understand that history will be their judge, and believe you me it will judge them all very badly. Madam President, a number of friendly pro-European colleagues within this Parliament have openly admitted to me that they cannot believe their luck in how bad a deal this is for the UK, and it surely cannot be allowed to proceed on such a one-sided basis. (Applause from some quarters)

name: Michel BARNIER
text: Chief Brexit Negotiator. Madam President, thank you to those who have spoken, in particular Guy Verhofstadt, Elmar Brok, Roberto Gualtieri, Philippe Lamberts and Gabriele Zimmer for expressing their appreciation on behalf of their group for the work we have done. I'm sensitive to that. It's a really collective effort. It has not been a solitary or personal work, it is a collective work. I was happy to participate because I know this House - I was elected there at one time - I also know the European Council and of course the Commission, and it seemed very important to me to work as a worker - I hope qualified - to this unity between the 27 and between the institutions. The assessment relates to the work of my team, Task Force 50, and I will obviously pass it on to my assistant, Sabine Weyand, to Stephanie Riso and to the whole team that has earned this appreciation and who will receive it as an encouragement. However, we are in a serious and sad moment, as you have said. Also, I say to Mr Farage and others that I do not want to make controversies. I have never done one and I am not going to start today. We listen to everyone, we respond to everyone, we talk to everyone and we will continue. It remains, as Gabriele Zimmer said, the time for ratification and, in the coming months, we must prepare for the future negotiation that we need, on other legal bases, for the partnership with the United Kingdom. We must be vigilant, as Guy Verhofstadt has pointed out, also on the implementation of what is in this Treaty, in particular on the rights of citizens and the guarantees that must be confirmed and implemented in order for the procedures for European citizens in the United Kingdom to be inexpensive and as simple as possible. Therefore, vigilance and determination are required.  This vote, which is expected on both sides, commits the future of the Union. It commits the future of the United Kingdom. I say this with the respect mentioned earlier for the time of the democratic debate in the United Kingdom, which we respect. The United Kingdom, by its culture, by its history, by its solidarity, especially in the great tragic moments that Europe went through in the 20th century, its total solidarity, by its economy, by the quality of its diplomacy, is a very great country. I have respect for this country and that is why I hope that as soon as possible we can work towards a true partnership unprecedented by the scope of the subjects of cooperation to consolidate our alliance beyond what we are already doing for many countries in the Atlantic Alliance obviously or bilaterally to strengthen our partnership in another framework and to consolidate our friendship as well. Mr Farage, in this negotiation I have sometimes been asked whether the Union will make concessions. No, there was never any question in my mind that there was a winner or a loser. Brexit is "lose-lose." There is no added value. Therefore, it is a matter of taking into account your sovereign decision - I say sovereign, Mr Lebreton. We respect this sovereign decision of a majority of British citizens and implement it according to the indications, demands and red lines expressed by the Government of London. I have worked with Theresa May's government throughout this year and a half and on the terms of what she said she accepted or did not accept. How else do you want me to do it? We negotiated with the government of London, which expressed a desire to leave the European Union following the referendum, and then to leave the single market, because you no longer want to respect the regulatory framework, because you no longer want to respect the freedom of movement of people, because you no longer want to recognise the role of the Court of Justice and you no longer want to pay. In addition, you are leaving the customs union because you no longer want to be in a common trade policy. These are the red lines that are yours and we respect them. But you must respect our determination to preserve the foundations of the European Union, and in particular this single market. I had the honour of being its commissioner for five years. This single market, it owes a lot to the United Kingdom. You have had a very great degree of influence in its construction and evolution, but you are leaving it because you no longer want to respect these four freedoms that are indivisible. I mean with great respect to Geoffrey van Orden: It's not inflexibility, it's not inflexibility; it is just responsibility. We have a duty, a responsibility, to work for an orderly withdrawal, to create security and stability where Brexit creates insecurity. It's only an orderly withdrawal that creates a basis of trust for the deep and ambitious partnership we all want.  That's what I meant. This negotiation is a negotiation because you are leaving the European Union. You have decided to leave the European Union and we regret that. It is obviously a negative negotiation, with no added value. That is why we have this feeling of seriousness, which does not forbid the lucidity on our side as well to learn the lessons of this Brexit. There are, as Guy Verhofstadt and Elmar Brok have said, lessons to be learned for ourselves, namely to understand the reasons for this vote and, if necessary, to change a number of things that should be done to better respond to the concerns, demands and sometimes anxieties of citizens.  That is, we have been working on this unity that European leaders have wanted in the very serious geopolitical context in which we are. To the west, to the east, to the south, we can see that we are being challenged from all sides and we have been working with this unity between the 27 Member States and between the institutions.  What I can simply express as a wish at this stage of this process which is not finished, because the road is long and is still very steep - we are waiting for the vote of 11 December and the ratification process on the British side on this agreement which is the only and the best possible - I simply and humbly hope that this unity that we have forged together in this negative negotiation , the European leaders of which you are a part decide to put it at the service of a positive agenda.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you, Mr Barnier, and could I thank you on behalf of the Parliament and President Tajani for your work with Parliament on this issue, your transparency and, above all else, your patience.  If I may say on a personal note, the word ‘rubbish’ has been bandied about. Mr Coburn, you use it frequently. It is not the view of the majority of this House.  The debate is closed.  Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. EU Member States last week approved the Withdrawal Agreement and the political declaration on the future relationship between the EU and the UK. This so-called "Brexit deal" has yet to be approved by the British Parliament in December. The aim is to continue to ensure successful economic and political cooperation between the EU and the UK. The Bank of England and the UK Treasury have now published studies in the run-up to the parliamentary debate in the House of Commons showing that a no-deal scenario could trigger a deep and damaging recession in the UK. A no-deal Brexit would send the UK economy into a severe supply shock, causing demand for goods and services to outpace supply, which would increase inflation. Britain's gross domestic product could fall by as far as 8% next year, the unemployment rate could rise from the current 4.1% to 7.5%, while interest rates would also rise with inflation of 6.5%.  The Brexit deal negotiated between the EU and Prime Minister May helps avoid this scenario, maintain close trade ties and achieve GDP growth of 1.75% over the next five years. In this way, both the result of the democratic referendum and economic interests were preserved.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. – Today Michel Barnier reports on the progress of the UK's withdrawal. The Brexit deal is yet to be approved by the British Parliament. Before our eyes, UKIP MEPs fought. Apparently, the division in the country has become even deeper. Analyses of British business show negative trends for the British economy. There's no good script! The least bad is for the British Parliament to approve the agreement. The vote will be on 11 December, but to be honest, there is no majority at this stage to be passed. In this case, many risks arise for the business and especially for the citizens, including the Bulgarians who are there. I'il take some practical advice to them. If the agreement is not accepted by the British Parliament, the most likely scenario is for the UK to leave without a deal. Do not rely on the ideas of a second referendum or early elections. In practice, this means that it will be extremely difficult, though not impossible, for some of the people who do not have the full documentation to prove their rights and to request the right to sede. Therefore, my advice is to start collecting your documents for legal residence, work, income, paid university fees, housing rents and health insurance from now on. That way you'il be prepared for a worst-case scenario.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – On the one hand, it is clear that the Brexit deal just signed is the only one possible in the circumstances. On the other hand it is equally clear that while the EU has safeguarded all its imperatives, the UK has retreated along all lines of engagement. In part this was because for various reasons, its negotiating positions and strategies were not so coherent. However the EU should be wary of driving its negotiating advantages as of now, to the extreme. This might lead to very serious unintended and unforeseeable consequences. In any agreement, a party that goes away with the feeling it has been given a raw deal, will later be tempted or driven to exact some form of compensation or retribution. Witness the Versailles treaty, or the Russian position over recent years in reaction to how post-Soviet arrangements in Europe were played out. Secondly, should there be any other EU government wishing to exit, it will have learnt the lesson of not doing it the British way under article 50 procedures. It could for instance first do its best to cause havoc from the inside in order to leverage and strengthen its position during exit negotiations.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. – The Brexit negotiations have shown that the European Union can cooperate at the highest level quickly and effectively. The European Council approved the agreement on the United Kingdom's departure from the European Union and issued a statement setting out the framework for future relations between the European Union and the United Kingdom. Our aim is to maintain the closeest possible partnership with the UK in the future. We are aware that Brexit is ultimately not beneficial for either side. The UK rejects the customs union because it wants to have its own trade agreements and no longer wants to be part of the common single market because it does not want to preserve the principle of four freedoms. Nevertheless, we must not forget that there are many spheres in which our cooperation is essential for both sides. Such areas are, for example, security, trade or science and research. At a time when Russia is visibly strengthening its influence in the countries of the former Soviet Union, cooperation with the UNITED Kingdom precisely in the area of security is crucial for our future.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. –It is a pity that the 2016 Brexit vote was largely based on incomplete and misinformation and completely unsubfitable promises that the British Government is practically unable to deliver on.  Britain's impending withdrawal from the EU is a major tragedy that could still be avoided. As such, the withdrawal agreement now negotiated corresponds to the minimum conditions imposed on it by the EUROPEAN Parliament. The Withdrawal Agreement safeguards the rights of EU citizens living in the UK, confirms the UK's future payment obligations to the EU and avoids a hard border between Ireland and Northern Ireland. Yet it is clear that both the UK and the EU will suffer as a result of Brexit. The main aim of this agreement is to reduce the damage caused by the withdrawal. It is also quite clear that Britain cannot receive better benefits outside the EU than member states. However, according to the preliminary main lines, the UK would like to be involved in almost all EU activities in the future. This raises the question of why Britain wants to leave at all?  The withdrawal agreement now being negotiated, with transitional periods, is the second best option we can achieve. The best solution would be for Britain to decide to call off its withdrawal. That would still be perfectly possible. It would be right and fair that the British people should at least have the opportunity to vote again on the withdrawal now that it is known what the difference means in practice. This, of course, is now entirely in British hands.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the council and Commission declarations on the preparation of the Intergovernmental Conference in Marrakesh on 10 and 11 December on the United Nations Global Compact on Migration (2018/2959(RSP)).

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for this opportunity to discuss the issue again after the debate we had in Strasbourg earlier this month. I’m aware that the delegation from Parliament will be present in Marrakech and that you attach great importance to this conference where the Global Compact of safe, orderly and regular migration is due to be politically endorsed. Since the first draft of the Global Compact was put on the table, Member States engaged in intensive discussions on this document in the Council, both during the Bulgarian and the Austrian Presidency. They also actively engaged in the discussions in New York. Indeed, since the adoption of the New York declaration for refugees and migrants in September 2016, the EU has actively engaged in providing input at the various stages of preparation of the first draft of the Global Compact. As you are aware the Council does not have a common position on this text. Member States have decided or are in the process of deciding their national position on the Global Compact. The political endorsement of the Global Compact in the intergovernmental conference in Marrakech followed by the adoption of this document by the UN General Assembly will open the way for the implementation phase. To conclude, I would recall that cooperation with third countries and regions remains a crucial element of the EU’s migration policy. The dialogues and the support we provide to our partners through a variety of instruments, including through the EU Trust Fund for Africa, are testimony to our commitment to a policy that recognises the specific responsibilities, needs and concerns of countries of origin, transit and destination. I can assure you that the Council and the Presidency will continue to contribute to that purpose.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: haute représentante de l’Union pour les affaires étrangères et la politique de sécurité/vice-présidente de la Commission européenne. – Monsieur le Président, Mesdames et Messieurs les députés, merci à vous tous pour l’attention constante que vous portez à ce débat sur le travail que font les Nations unies, mais aussi sur le thème de l’immigration, qui est un thème crucial de notre temps et de notre travail, en tant qu’institution européenne, avec les États membres, la Commission et le Parlement.  Madam President, I believe there are two mistakes we must not make when discussing the Global Compact, and one additional that I will mention later. The first one is to pretend that there is a clash between our national interests and the idea of a Global Compact. The opposite is true. If our national interest is to govern migration, and I believe it is – of all of us – to make it orderly, humane and sustainable, then the Global Compact is the most powerful tool we have to serve our national interests. The second mistake would be to tackle migration as a fight between the north and the south of the world: the developed and the developing countries. Again, the opposite is true. Let me mention just the fact that most of the countries are, at the same time – for instance, in Africa – countries of origin, of transit and of destination. Again, as I said, the opposite is true. It’s not north against south or south against north; we all share an interest in managing migration. We all have an interest in investing in sustainable development in the regions that need it the most, and we all have an interest in creating regular pathways for human mobility. The earlier we realise that it’s partnership and cooperation that we need, the better for us all, because we are all in this together. No country can address it on its own, neither in Europe nor elsewhere in the world, and all countries have an interest in addressing this effectively. We all support it. The UN Secretary—General Ban Ki-moon’s initiative to hold a high—level meeting on migration – that was back at the UN General Assembly in 2016. Then, we all, collectively and unanimously, adopted the New York Declaration that launched the work on the two Global Combats on refugees and on migration. And that was an important achievement for us Europeans, because in the middle of the migration crisis in Europe – I add ‘in Europe’ because we have to remind ourselves there are migration crises every single day in every single part of the world – but at that specific moment, after the summer of 2016, in the middle of the European migration crisis, Europe – us – we called for the international community to engage, to build partnerships, and we received a positive response. And there the Global Compact process started. The European Union took an early lead in the discussions on the Global Migration Compact. We also participated from the beginning, actively, in the work leading to the clear common positions that are now in front of us, and this has allowed us to bring forward a Global Compact that largely reflects European objectives and that respects all our key concerns. I know that Commission Stylianides said it very clearly in the European Parliament in the plenary session in Strasbourg a couple of weeks ago. We regret the decision by some European Union Member States not to join or to support the Global Compact on Migration. We do believe that all Member States’ interests are best served in supporting the proposed framework that will establish a basis for international cooperation and dialogue – that basis that was missing up to now and that we asked for: dialogue and cooperation that lie already at the basis of the first results that would need to be consolidated, that we have achieved as Europeans, in the past years: reducing irregular arrivals, offering alternatives to migrants, bringing smugglers to justice and also tackling difficult topics, including return and readmission. Results that were achieved by way of cooperation, partnership and mutual respect and understanding, with a strong role of the United Nations – all elements that are the basis of the Global Compact. There are some misconceptions in the debate on the Global Compact, as I said already. I would like to underline one that is self—evident to me, but maybe we need to repeat it in view of the national debates that are going on. It is not a legally-binding framework. I think national parliaments in particular, but also the European Parliament, have to acknowledge that from the very beginning: it is not legally binding. It will not create any legal obligation for the states. It is a menu of policy actions; it is a menu of best practices from which states may draw to implement their national migration policies in a cooperative way and in any international manner. It provides a framework. The Compacts are built on this basis and are grounded on the respect of the principle of national and sovereign rights of states to determine their national migration policies. But they do provide that framework that is missing today, and that is definitely needed, as we Europeans asked for it. We will continue to work to improve migration management worldwide, which is already done today on the European side, on the basis of the work strands that are developed under the Global Compact. We will, notably, continue our engagement with the International Organisation for Migration, who will lead the implementation and follow—up of the Compact, which will entail sharing experiences, helping countries to overcome shortcomings, and searching for solutions to an issue that is global, by definition. We will also continue to support partnerships at bilateral, regional and global level in the area of migration. With our partners in the world, the Migration Compact will be an important basis for cooperation along what has been agreed as the common European Union approach to migration. And that, as I said, is largely reflected in the Compact. So here, our common work and your contribution as the European Parliament will be essential. Mr Avramopoulos will be leading the Commission delegation to Marrakech on 10 and 11 December, and I’m very happy to see that Members of the European Parliament will join the European Union delegation to the Intergovernmental Conference at Marrakech. I believe the role of Parliament is going to be crucial. I very much appreciate the European Parliament’s strong interest and engagement and confirm our full commitment to work very closely with you in this joint endeavour.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Dear Chairman, Respected Distinguished Commissioner, as a member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Development Committee, I have visited crisis hotspots in the world meeting many refugees and have seen that they all have one common goal - to find a safe haven for themselves and their family.  In 2015, we saw that only one spark was enough to disrupt the delicate peace in the Western Balkans with a refugee wave heading for Europe. Croatia, which has the longest land border to the Western Balkans, knows this very well. Italy and Spain with sea borders to Africa were most exposed to refugee waves and could not lift walls. Member States of the European Union and the Member States of the United Nations should not approach this problem individually either, but also participate and act together in the creation of comprehensive solutions.  I regret that the Global Agreement on Migration is running into controversy, but I hope that a middle way will be found, as the European Parliament did in its resolution on the Global Agreement, on which I worked as a negotiator on behalf of the European People's Party, which will serve as a roadmap on how to proceed in this matter in a humane and acceptable manner.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. It is the responsibility of politicians to explain the decisions credibly. In April, the European Parliament supported the global agreement by a large majority, as it underlines the importance of human rights, which are universal. To those who say that the global agreement is about importing migrants, the national betrayal or betrayal of sovereignty and the destruction of Western civilisation, which is also accusations by the slovenian public, that such intimidation of people is wrong and misleading. It is a political declaration based on cooperation, the sovereignty of states, the division of responsibility, based on a global, European and national legal order that does not equalify migrants with refugees and does not bring about new legal obligations.  Global challenges can only be solved together. I just got back from Niger State. There is a struggle for a decent life part of everyday life, as rich Western countries abuse natural resources and people.  As long as that is the case, Europe will be an attractive continent. That is why the global agreement is of great importance so that migration can be safe, controlled and regulated, and that this will be a global concern for all of us, which europeans expect of us.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: for the ECR Group. Mr President! The Marrakesh Declaration is a shame of cultural radical and liberal ideas that have brought Europe into the morass we see today, when the Member States have turned against each other, because we can no longer hijack the enormous illegal immigration that is taking place. So what is the solution if you ask the UN? It is to recognise a concept as 'climate refugees', it is to give migrants social rights, and that is to talk about integration rather than the repatriation of refugees, whose stay must by definition be temporary until they are given protection.  Fortunately, we are approaching ten EU Member States that will not sign this crazy document, including sensible countries outside the EU such as Switzerland, the US and Australia. However, it is shameful that my own country of Denmark has not yet taken the decision not to sign the Marrakesh Declaration, even though the government's own political positions are in direct contradiction with its content. Therefore, an invitation to my own government in Denmark to follow the sensible ones in the EUROPEAN Union, do not go to Marrakesh, do not sign this UN madness!

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, what a schizophrenia! On the one hand, Mrs Edstädtler, State Secretary in the Austrian Government, speaks on behalf of the European Council. She talks around it, but the Austrian government won't sign it. On the other side is Mrs Mogherini, who represents not only the European Commission but also the Council. Fortunately, it does embrace the Global Pact for Safe and Ordered Migration. As Europe, we are a real fool! That Donald Trump wasn't going to be in it made sense. But we, in the Europe of soft forces, went on to show the world that you can all come to agreements to ensure that children of migrants go to school, that a return policy is pursued, and that children are not left without papers but can have an existence. This was our moment to ensure that we were no longer held hostage by the migration crisis from 2015 onwards. But what do we do? We make it an internal game and we forget that we set standards that also apply to Africa and Asia.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I find it astonishing that several EU countries are now withdrawing from the global agreement on migration, under pressure of nationalism and racism. On the left, we see major problems with the text in the run-up to Marrakech, but we fully support the need for global objectives and processes to manage migration within the framework of the UN.  Migration is not a problem. It is the exploitation of migrants, for example in the European labour market, that is a problem. We need to review our foreign policy, the arms trade in Europe, our climate emissions, which means that people are moving away and having to move and migrate. That is what needs to be changed. We must also have these negotiations on a more equal basis between North and South.  I think that this failure clearly also shows that europe is on the wrong track, that we have not been able to agree on anything here at home, that we are not accepting refugees with dignity, that we are allowing death in the Mediterranean to continue, that we are setting up 10 000 border guards instead of talking about how to deal with migration and refugees in a dignified and human rights-based way. The criminalisation of the NGO that is going on now is terrible. I do not see why we ...  (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the EFDD Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the We are talking again about the Global Compact for Migration, because the left-green-utopian migration lobby hopes that this House will send out an affirmative signal for a world of borderless migration. The opposite is true. Yesterday, the Italian Government finally decided not to approve the pact. It is thus part of an ever-increasing list of states that refuse to accept this absurd agenda. The US rejects the pact, as do Australia and Israel, Hungary, Austria, Slovakia, Poland, the Czech Republic and Bulgaria in the EU. Belgium therefore has a government crisis. A crisis is also looming in Germany, because the previous supporters are now dawning on what further madness Mrs Merkel wants to push our country into next.  So no one is saying that the European Parliament is even halfway united behind the signing of this sneaky pact. Because that is not true, it is not even true at all. Let this fake news! Enough. Let us stop this suicidal pact before it is too late!

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. A good day begins with another country not joining the UN migration pact, Italy said yesterday. Thanks to Matteo Salvini, who was the driving force behind this, just as Heinz-Christian Strache was the driving force behind Austria's failure to join this pact. USA, Australia, Hungary, Poland, Czech Republic, Bulgaria, Slovakia, Slovenia – more and more people are saying "no" to this.  And if you look at the main objectives of the United Nations quite honestly, it has nothing to do with the UN migration pact. The main objectives are to ensure disarmament, peace, security and friendship, to guarantee human rights and also to be a meeting place. But the United Nations certainly does not have the aim of resolving the issue of migration worldwide and thus intervening accordingly in the decision-making authority of national parliaments and their representatives.  This pact is a bad thing; more and more countries are recognising it. I am pleased with any other country that does not join this pact.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I am very surprised, Mrs Mogherini, as you can say, that this pact is not a binding right for nations, if, after four years, the nations are to be checked to see whether they have implemented the measures of this pact. And when, on the one hand, I imagine that integration is now becoming the new magic word and that there is no longer any thought about repatriation, that we no longer think about what the Geneva Convention on Refugees actually says, namely that those migrants should be repatriated when peace is restored in their homeland. None of this is taken into account. Integration should be the magic word in the future rather than repatriation. The peoples of Europe are threatened by this migration pact, and many peoples have now found the answer not to sign it. I do not think that the migrants have a real future with this pact either. Because the future should not lie in coming to Europe ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Mr President, the Global Compact is important as it recognises that migration is a global challenge that requires a global response and solidarity. There is nothing binding. Richer countries have to share responsibility and, for example, do more resettlement. I regret that Trump turned them back but, even worse, that some Member States walked out. To just say ‘go home and stay home’ is no solution. No state can deal with migration alone. A common European response and global cooperation is the way forward to safe and legal migration because Europe must work with third countries, from prevention to combating trafficking, and to implement return. It is also crucial to invest in Africa in the long term. I was in Agadez in Niger with the European Parliament delegation and, thanks to the EU’s effective action, we have reduced migration, we have saved lives, and we are combating trafficking: more of those partnerships. I look forward to participating, on behalf of the PPE Group, in the European Parliament... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. The Global Compact is an important contribution to responses to the global challenge of migration and asylum. The draft spells out the frameworks and makes it clear that the protection of refugees and the application for asylum are human rights that cannot be called into question.  It is more than regrettable that there are some EU countries whose leaders are unwilling to accept the Global Compact for self-righteous political reasons and reasons. We need to know that those who reject this declaration are not interested in solving the problem, and on the contrary, they are interested in making sure that the issue of refugees and immigration is not resolved, because that is how they make political capital for themselves. This is immeasurable irresponsibility, shameful, immoral and inhumane politics, the consequences of which will hit us all. That is why we must raise our voices against hate and fear-mongering, in addition to shared responsibility.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Vice-President Mogherini has just said that the Global Compact has no legally binding impact on countries. So, I wonder if there will be a big conference in Marrakech on 10 and 11 December to discuss this.  The truth is that on immigration – a great failure of European policies in recent years – a cultural and political game is being played with the Global Compact, and it is absolutely right that we should not sign and participate in an initiative in which uncertainty is absolute and, above all, we are only trying to put in place targeted political action so that we can continue on the wrong path. I have listened to several colleagues who have spoken about Italy's withdrawal: Italy has been discussing the Global Compact for a few days thanks to the action of Giorgia Meloni of Fratelli d'Italia, which has been part of a government in which the situation is unclear: Salvini said not to go and not to participate in Marrakech; Prime Minister Conte said otherwise. We'il see what happens. We will work hard to ensure that Italy does not participate.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am not going to quote Mr Salvini, and I quote Pope Francis who, in the Chamber of the European Parliament, has warned Europe, saying, and I quote: 'if it is able to clearly propose its cultural identity and defend, in addition to the right to reception, the rights of citizens, helping these peoples in their country'. Apart from President Tajani's invocations, which seem to fall on a Marshall Plan, Europe is not responding to this.  The word identity does not exist in this text: it is said that the sovereignty of states is protected, but then it is made clear that it must be subordinated to international agreements and is therefore a limited sovereignty. I believe that we must draw inspiration from the teachings of those who have a certain idea of Europe, such as Pope Francis. If Pope Francis had written it, I, in a closed box, would sign it immediately! I believe that this is also the approach of the Italian Government, which is not insensitive to the rights of those fleeing persecution, etc., but which intends to put an end to the obscene trade in migrants who only serve ...  (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I will be in Marrakech with Parliament's delegation. The Global Compact provides a global twist to the theme of migration, giving continuity to our work started with the resolution on the holistic approach to migration. Too many Member States have decided to sabotage the Intergovernmental Conference: I say to these countries, especially my own, Italy: go there! Orban, Salvini and all the leaders of the countries that have decided to take this step: go to Marrakech, come with me, come with us!  Opposing the global pact means not only opposing solutions for safer and more regular migration, but much worse: opposing the dignity and human rights of migrants! Don't stay out of history: that's the story! And immigration won't stop. Immigration continues. We must be responsible for tackling the root causes of immigration. Once again, the hypocrisy of the Italian Government emerges, preaching the responsibility to deal with the phenomenon of migration in solidarity and then opposing proposals (The President interrupts the speaker).

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: For the catch-the-eye procedure that follows, I have to tell you that I have twice as many notifications as time is set aside. We shall have a very long vote today. I therefore ask for leniency if I cannot take all my fellow Members into account. Spontaneous speeches

name: Milan ZVER
text: – Mr President-in-Office, I am one of those who opposes the Marrakesh Declaration, mainly because it does not represent a global agreement, it is neither global nor an agreement.  It has already been relinquished by big countries, major global players such as the US, Australia, Israel, more than a dozen European member states, and this is certainly not a general agreement. In Slovenia, 70 percent of the public is against it. Not even political elites have been able to come around it, let alone the European and global public.  Above all, I am against this because the text is bad, because it is based on the wrong assumptions, and it is also not true that it is not binding, yet how binding it is, if you read it thoroughly, this work.  In short, I am opposed to this agreement because it will further worsen the situation in migration management in the future.  The European Union should invest much more, more effort and money into the countries of origin from which migration comes, but in no way in this way to solve this problem.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Clearly, those who oppose the migration pact have not read it. They are all about populism and party politics. After all, what is rejected, what is in this migration pact? For example, collecting data to provide a basis for migration policy, or looking to prevent the drivers that people are leaving their homes for, or collecting accurate and timely information at all stages of migration – rejected, as well as saving lives and coordinating international action when there are missing migrants. It also rejects the cross-border fight against smugglers or integrated, secure and coordinated border management. Our government does not even want opportunities to be created to ensure faster, safer and cheaper remittances of migrants to their home countries.
