name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Dear Chairman, the need to create a framework for migration globally exists, as it is evident that a large number of countries do not respect the international order and openly miss migrants towards their final destinations. Tens of thousands of people at the moment undocumented, with a false identity and no real vetting cross borders and head for one of the Western states, while those who miss them turn a blind eye to the problem and thus threaten all of us. Migration must be safer for both migrants and the domiciled population. A lot of people have entered Europe that to this day we don't know who they are and what their real intentions are.  The UN Compact on Migration does not present this framework for a solution to this global challenge, as it is rejected by the Americans, Australia, Israel and a number of European states. This means that it is mostly supported by those states from which people leave, but not by those who should receive them. That's not how the problem is solved, it's only getting worse.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Mr President-in-Office, such a global agreement would, of course, be needed much earlier, and we would have done much easier with the cooperation of all the countries to solve the many problems we are facing today.  And the fact is that this global deal also means effective migration management, which is also a defence of the sovereignty and security of countries, which opponents of this agreement are trying to argue with. And also security for those weakest in the fleeting caravans.  This declaration, of course, this agreement has great ambitions, and if we read all the objectives, which are a summary of the content itself, we see that it offers solutions for which we have not found a proper agreement to date.  And I think it is really unreasonable to reject such initiatives, but the fact is that the solution can be found by all of us together, but it is very difficult for each country to be here, and there is no high fence here.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, the global pact on immigration is a text not only useless, but also dangerous. First of all, it recognises the right to mass mobilisation and movement for economic reasons to anyone from a third country who wants to enter or even invade - above all - Europe and the United States. Secondly, there is confusion between who is legal and who is an illegal immigrant. As a result, states cannot follow an independent national immigration policy and protect their borders. Furthermore, there is a risk that, in the future, the non-binding - at the moment - objectives mentioned in the draft will become binding provisions and, taking into account the anchors and the persistence of the Left, it will not be surprising if any criticism of the phenomenon of illegal immigration becomes a criminal offence. That is precisely why many states no longer seek to sign this text.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I want to underline the fact that I am speaking here on behalf of the Commission. It’s for the Austrian Presidency to express the position of the Council. The Commission has a very clear position on the Global Compact. As I explained, this is the result of a process that we Europeans have initiated in the UN Framework, asking for partnership and asking to have a political global framework for managing together, on the basis of what we had already started to do with our African friends, with our Asian friends, and with friends from Latin America and everywhere. We initiated this process in the UN Framework, asking for a global approach – political, not legally binding – to establish partnerships because we Europeans found out – in my view quite late, in 2015-2016, but still we did – that we needed to build strong partnerships with the countries of origin, of transit and of destination, supporting a common system and a common approach to manage migration, fight traffickers, offer opportunities and also to tackle, as some of you have said, difficult issues like returns, in an effective manner. It’s a difficult process, but it’s a process that is now reflected in a Compact that, starting from a European approach, has moved to a global level. As I said, the Compact largely reflects the positions of the European Union and the work that we are currently doing, together with our partners, on migration, starting from the work we’re doing with the International Organisation for Migration (IOM) and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNNHCR). I can tell you this: the Commission will not only be represented in Marrakesh with a delegation, as I said, led by Commissioner Avramopoulos, but will continue to actively engage with the UN and with the UN system on its implementation. Technically, as you might know – but maybe not – after the Conference in Marrakech, there will be a vote in the General Assembly, where Member States of the UN will take a vote, but the Commission will continue to work with the UN system, with the UN agencies and with our partners globally to implement this agenda because we have seen that, in the first couple of years of work that we have done, along the lines that are reflected in the Global Compact, these have started to bring results. So we will continue to work in this direction, investing in the Global Compact’s implementation as a political, non—binding, cooperative framework that will guide our work over the coming decades.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, High Representative, honourable Members, it was useful to have this discussion today in view of the conference next month and of the forthcoming adoption of the Global Compact in New York. I would like to conclude by reiterating what I already stated at the beginning, and that is the fact that migration in general and more specifically cooperation with third countries will remain high on the agenda of the Council and the Presidency. Therefore we will continue to contribute to that purpose. I would like to thank you for sharing your doubts, your questions, your concerns, and also your thoughts in this regard.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. – If the UN's global migration package is thoroughly read, it becomes clear that it does not reflect Europe's interests and is even harmful and dangerous to Europe. The document makes migration a positive phenomenon, blurs illegal economic migration with the issue of genuine refugees and legal migration, and describes illegal migration as a fundamental right. It would require countries to inform migrants about migration routes and launch information campaigns for them. It would also facilitate the family reunification of migrants and provide migrants with the same services as the citizens of that country. The word obligation is mentioned 80 times in the document, so it is far from true that it only makes recommendations. The adoption of the package would therefore have irreversible consequences because of the development of interpretation and customary law, which would become a point of reference and a basis for international justice. This is contrary to the interests of the European people. Hungary the example of the European Union, eight countries have already decided to withdraw from the adoption process of the package, and many other Member States are considering withdrawing from the migration compact. I see that common sense is starting to return to our continent, and more and more people are realizing that this is a document that is in breach of national interests and dangerous to our Europe, which clearly divides the Union.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. – The USA, Austria, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic and Hungary are the countries that have given up on signing the Marrakesh Declaration, while Slovakia, Poland, Estonia, Australia, Israel and Switzerland have strong reservations under the Declaration and state that they will not participate in the ratification of the Declaration. The withdrawal of these states from the ratification of the Declaration should urge us to exercise some caution.  What worries me most, within the text of the Declaration, is the fact that the boundaries between legal and illegal migration are being erased. No matter that the Declaration constitutes a non-binding document, Member States can include it in their legislation, which can create long-term problems in terms of migration and sovereignty in the future.  The EU was wrong in its approach to migration, did not address them where they originated, but further encouraged migrant waves through its adopted policy. I think it is important to help people fleeing war and show them with our humanity that we are with them, but when it comes to economic migration, it is necessary to create social, economic and political conditions in the countries from which migrants come, so that they can stay and live decently in their homeland.  I believe that the EU must not put pressure on member states, but must decide for themselves whether to join the Marrakesh Declaration and should be given the opportunity to decide for themselves whether and how many migrants they can take into their country.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – I consider the Global Framework on Safe, Orderly and Regular Migration to be a serious policy document that should have guaranteed that the problem of migration in the world is coordinated, that it has a single platform and that states jointly face the migration challenges that are everywhere in the world. Unfortunately, in addition to good proposals, the document also raises points that are controversial and therefore unacceptable to many states. Although the preamble to Article 7 states that the global legal framework constitutes a non-binding framework, Article 9 then states that this global framework sets out our common understandings, common responsibilities, shared responsibilities and unity of purpose in relation to migration in order to benefit all. The document has 23 objectives, some of which we can agree with, but some are unacceptable. Surely everyone agrees to minimise the adverse incentives and structural factors that force people to leave their country. On the other hand, the point is about the integration of migrants and their inclusion, their education, their financial support, which should only be adopted by countries in need of migrants for their economies. The UN should be aware that inconsistencies in the evaluation of a document is a serious moment, so it should seek compromise proposals as soon as possible, because migration problems need to be tackled together.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on the situation of women with disabilities by Rosa Estar's Ferragut on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality (O-000117/2018 – B8-0418/2018) (2018/2685(RSP)).

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: Author. – Mr President, we speak today on behalf of the more than 46 million women with disabilities; they account for 16.6% of the total population of the European Union. Today, with this debate, we are going to make them more visible. We're going to be his speaker. Today we are going to create an image that really favors that they can exercise their rights. They are, above all, human beings.  They are citizens who cannot be defined by their disability and, in fact, do not want to be. They face the same problems every day as other women: they are mothers, daughters, friends, workers; they have a multitude of talents and a multitude of skills and enrich our society by making it more diverse. The contribution they can make is crucial, and that is why it must be promoted and ensured that the plans these women have will be heard.  Today, with this debate, we are going to create a positive awareness of diversity and we will make the culture of difference impose, because it is the one that generates the most social advantages.  These women face the challenge of making them invisible every day. Women who do not see, who do not hear, who live otherwise, who have no mobility; in short, women with disabilities are women that society excludes. These are often mental barriers: invisibiliza, and this results in a great deal of discrimination in all sectors in all countries.  We will talk about education—inclusive education—which means that we all participate freely in society and all contribute and contribute to it. When discriminated against in education, the student diverse from this exclusion is found guilty; that can't happen. Inclusive and accessible work and education are the tools to be able to link ourselves to a society and to be able to participate in all sectors; only 18.8% of women with disabilities are employed in the European Union, a smaller percentage than their male counterparts or who undoubtedly have no disability.  We also need to talk about digital literacy, because an important group of these women are over sixty years old and that is why we will have to develop a strategy for older and disabled women.  We will also talk about the need for full participation in all the issues of women with disabilities; they can't be left out of anything; and, of course, ensure the active and passive suffrage of these women. A legislative amendment has recently been made in Spain in this regard. We will talk about equal treatment: the need for all of us to be equal — one of the values of the European Union. This will have to create active and public policies in order to break down all barriers to such equality and, above all, to give truthful, simple and effective information to these women so that they can develop their rights.  Accessibility is the prerequisite for participation and equality. It is true that on 8 November we have been informed that the Council and the Commission have already agreed to this European Accessibility Act, which is more than we had and less than we asked for, but that it is a step forward to work in a Europe without barriers. Accessibility means that everything is done in all languages, in all forms, in all formats. Think that, for example, in gynecological checkups, women with disabilities have accessibility issues going for a mammogram or gynecological checkup. There is difficulty in accessibility to many health services, many services against gender-based violence, support services, maternity services, protection, communication. We have to break those barriers. The social pillar is an opportunity to be able to include women with disabilities and also make them protagonists.  And we'll talk about dignity, too. We must get out of the silence of harassment suffered by these women: one in three women with disabilities has been or will be mistreated and a victim of gender-based violence. That's why we need a strategy of support and respect in this regard. And we will also talk about another way of discriminating, such as forced sterilization, coercive abortion or excluding them from the right to adoption or motherhood. It is also a full-rule discrimination and involves inhumane treatment. And we will also talk about the need to have indicators to know what the situation is for these women; gender indicators; indicators of disability in the European Disability Strategy itself and in all departments. And I end by telling you that Goal 5 of the Sustainable Development Goals was talking about empowering women. Empowering women with disabilities is empowering humanity. Today we have an opportunity to learn, to feel, to live and to create. "Being a woman," says a disabled, good friend, " Love it; I have a disability and I have many capacities like anyone else, but first and foremosm I am a human being, with all the rights that correspond to me; I hope I never have to justify why again."

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members of Parliament, fundamental rights, inclusive growth and social fairness are at the core of this Commission’s agenda. We are working hard to make sure that no one is left behind, and I would like to think Madam Estaràs Ferragut and the FEMM Committee for putting forward this question on the situation of women with disabilities. The Commission has undertaken important legislative initiatives for fostering the participation of persons with disabilities in society and for promoting gender equality. Just to give you two examples: the European Accessibility Act, on which there has recently been a provisional agreement among co-legislators, will break down barriers to key products and services. The Accessibility Act will, in particular, be a key tool to bridge the digital divide. Secondly, the Commission has proposed a work-life balance package in order to enable carers – mainly women – to better balance work and caring responsibilities. This is a key initiative to contribute to bridging the existing employment gap, pay gap and pension gap between men and women, and I hope the ongoing trilogues will produce results soon. Let me now respond to the three questions you’ve put forward. Together with all of our Member States, the European Union has committed to implement the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The European Disability Strategy is the main instrument to support the Union’s implementation of the Convention until 2020. It is part of the wider efforts under the Europe 2020 strategy to succeed in creating smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. Indeed, full economic and social participation of people with disabilities is essential to fulfil the objectives of the European 2020 strategy. The Commission is currently preparing an evaluation of the implementation of the current European Disability Strategy. The evaluation will cover all aspects of this ability. This includes, in particular, the situation of women and girls with disabilities and the challenges stemming from inter-sectional discrimination. And of course, as part of our preparations, we will consult as many stakeholders as possible. We will take into account the European Parliament’s views, such as last year’s resolution on the concluding observations of the UN Committee. Now on the gender-disaggregated data. Reliable and accurate data are essential for policy development. The Commission already disaggregates by gender the disability-related data it collects, including within the European semester. These data provide us with an objective basis for identifying intersectional discrimination. Our data show, for instance, that in the areas of poverty risk and employment, women with disabilities are disadvantaged compared to men with disabilities. In the area of education, however, we observe a higher percentage of early school-leaving with boys with disabilities than with girls. Attention to gender equality is also paid in the Union’s external action activities. We notably provide support to partner countries to improve data collection disaggregated by sex and disability. There is also the obligation to complete a gender analysis for each development cooperation project or programme. As a last point, I want to address the question on what the Commission is doing to enable participation of women with disabilities in the European elections. My colleague, Commissioner Jourová, has delivered a statement on the participation of people with disabilities in the European elections at the European Parliament’s plenary session on 5 July this year, and she pointed out the Commission’s recommendation of February 2018, which addresses the exchange of best practices with a view to promote the exercise of electoral rights of under-represented groups, including persons with disabilities. In April this year we followed up with a dedicated session on this topic, involving our network of Member States experts in electoral matters, and this week, on 26 and 27 November, we dedicated the annual colloquium on fundamental rights to democracy and the European Union, including the promotion of broad participation as a condition for inclusive democratic societies. And finally, I want to mention that the directive on the accessibility of public sector bodies’ websites, which came into effect last September, will contribute to assuring the accessibility of information issued by public bodies across the Union about political participation and elections. Thank you again for these questions.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for First of all, I congratulate Rosie Esteraz on the excellent text of the resolution on the situation of women with disabilities. There are 80 million people with disabilities living in Europe, 46 million of them women. Only 18% of them have employment. Disabled people are mainly cared for by women. 80% of them do so informally and free of charge. It's a closed circle of inequality, endless effort and injustice.  Why do so few disabled women enter the labour market? What or lack of rules prevent the economic independence of women with disabilities? It's not just a matter of money, untapped talent and competence. It is also a question of human dignity linked to being an independent person and fully involved in social and economic life. After all, today's technologies, as the resolution draws attention, offer people with disabilities great opportunities to lead a normal life and self-realization.  Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for The recommendations of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and the European Disability Strategy should be put into practice as soon as possible. I also call on the Commission and the Member States to review and fully apply the rules for persons with disabilities, to include universal design principles in these provisions and to make better use of digital technologies and medical advances, so as to increase the independence, employability, and freedom and dignity of women and men with disabilities.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, we should talk about the rights of people with disabilities, the rights of women with disabilities and the improvement of their quality of life, and we should talk and look for solutions not only on the eve of the day for people with disabilities, but we must work on this issue on a permanent basis – together with the Commission, the Member States, of course, involving public organisations for people with disabilities. We are increasingly talking about the European Pillar of Social Rights, about the European strategy for disability, but unfortunately we are not able to reduce discrimination against people with disabilities, especially women with disabilities, and we are in no way able to guarantee the simplest things that seem to these people, namely work, income, inclusion in civic and political life.  The unemployment rate of people with disabilities remains unacceptable and is therefore at a significantly higher risk of poverty and social exclusion. In addition, women with disabilities face greater barriers to access to the labour market, which makes it more difficult for them to live a normal and independent life, as work is not only a source of income, but also a means of social inclusion, helping to reach out to wider society. Women with disabilities are often underpaid, and what to say about their old-age pensions at old age. Another problem is that data on the nature of the work of women with disabilities and the employment situation are generally limited. And in the absence of specific data broken down by gender, it is very difficult to deal with cases of discrimination, and I therefore, Commissioner, I call on the Commission as a whole to set up specific measures to address these problems, to ensure adequate funding through the Structural Funds of the European Union.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Our sensitivity to the needs of people with disabilities is manifested on the eve of International Day of Persons with Disabilities. For me, however, it is a little hypocritical that, in view of the forthcoming Day of Persons with Disabilities in the European Parliament, we are addressing the issues of those whom we should support and whom we should create opportunities and opportunities for education, professional development, access to cultural goods. It is worth asking today why the European Parliament is acting in a joint act. Beyond political divisions, we should take action that will allow people with disabilities to simply live with dignity. It is a pity that you are throwing in this document – here I am turning to the left of the parliamentary chamber – topics related to gender reassignment. I think it is regrettable that in such an important... (The President received the speaker's vote)

name: Tilly METZ
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report Do we really respect the UN Convention on the Rights of People with Disabilities? No! People with a disability are still discriminated against, and especially women with disabilities – in the field of training, in the field of work, but also in the field of personal and private development.  But everyone has the right to be happy. Everyone has the right to live a self-determined life – a life where sexuality is not taboo, a life where I can live out my sexuality, but where "no" also means "no", the right to start a family, the right to marry or to live with my partner. And it is precisely in these areas that women with disabilities need our support and support. This is not about pity, it is about a fundamental human right.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, the European Union cannot resign itself from responsibilities in the degradation of the socio-economic situation of people with disabilities, where women are doubly discriminated against. The austerity policies it promotes, the cutting of social and labor rights, the conditioning of investment in the budgets of states in areas such as health, education or social support do not dissociate themselves from the social setback of this fringe of the population. Every day, fundamental rights are denied to people with disabilities. In the difficulties of access to employment with rights, in the limitations and inadequacy of professional training, in the perpetuation of poverty and exclusion, in the lack of human, material and pedagogical resources in public schools for the proper monitoring and effective inclusion of children and young people, in the difficulties in accessing health care, medicines and targeted therapies, in the persistent limitations to mobility and access to culture and sport, among others.  A reality that requires the strengthening of public policies and responses that fully respond to the needs of people with disabilities.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, ensuring a level playing field for women with disabilities, whether in education, health or the workplace, should be taken for granted. However, this is not the case in some areas. Disabled women, for example, often have trouble seeking help from ordinary doctors in practice. These women face a burdened approach in other services and face various forms of violence. This motion for a resolution contains a number of important challenges that should improve this situation for women. It draws attention to these problems and hopes that this resolution will provide a boost for states to ensure better services. Nevertheless, I must draw attention to issues with which I disagree. I do not agree with the recommendation for the adoption of the Istanbul Convention, the inclusion of sexual and reproductive health issues and specific healthcare for transgender people. I believe that these calls have no place in such a resolution and therefore, I fear, I will not be able to support it.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Mr President, it is a fact that, through the debate on discrimination against women and against people with disabilities, a major issue is emerging for the European Union: that it is not only women with disabilities who are discriminated against, but discrimination against all women, at all levels. I believe that the European Union should be a pioneer and a leader, and should fully and fully implement the principle of non-discrimination between men and women.  Gender equality in the European Union has been, is and remains a basic, inviobable and inviolable principle that everyone must apply, and in particular the European Commission. It's not just about words and proclamations. The declarations are here and there is now the possibility for the European Commissioner and the European Commission to commit themselves to full and absolute implementation with regard to gender equality and to imposing sanctions on those Member States that do not apply the principle of gender equality. It is only in this way that the principle of gender equality will be fully and fully applied.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur for calling attention to the situation of women with disabilities through this motion for a resolution. Women with disabilities often face intersex discrimination because of their gender and disability. They are two to five times more likely to experience violence and sexual abuse than women without disabilities, especially if they have an intellectual disability. They are also under-represented in the labour market and in politics. As a result, many women with disabilities feel that they are excluded from society. I sincerely hope that the Equality Commission will take this explicitly into account in the draft EU Disability Strategy 2030 so that discrimination against women and girls with disabilities can be addressed vigorously. Equality, non-discrimination, respect and equal opportunities for women with disabilities. Not words but deeds, now!

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, I think the debate has revealed that there are, unfortunately, discrimination against women with disabilities. And what we need is not to say too much; not to take as an excuse that 3 December is the International Day of Persons with Disabilities to have this debate. We must take concrete measures and we have repeatedly said in our speeches to the plenary of the European Parliament that the UN Convention on Persons with Disabilities must be implemented.  There should also be no discrimination. There should be no discrimination against women who are disabled. We see this happening; there is difficulty in accessing the labour market. All the more so in Greece, where discrimination is very strong and, because of the memorandums, disability benefits have also been reduced. Measures are therefore needed specifically to be able to tackle this social problem.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this debate shows once more the relevance of the strategic and long-term approach we have chosen for both the specific issues of gender equality and disability. I should mention here that gender equality, equal opportunities and the inclusion of persons with disabilities are also among the principles of the European Pillar of Social Rights, which was jointly proclaimed just over a year ago by all three European political institutions. There is no doubt that the considerable input of the European Parliament over the past years will feed into the reflection about the form and the content of future European disability policies. The Commission is also committed to ensure the involvement of people with disabilities and their representative organisations in this reflection. I count on the European Parliament and, of course, also on the Member States to be strong allies in putting the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities into practice.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: A motion for a resolution has been tabled in accordance with Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place today, 29 November 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. – Women and girls with disabilities are particularly vulnerable to the threat of discrimination and violence. Available statistics show that, compared to a healthy population, a disabled woman is up to several times more likely to be subjected to violence or some form of abuse. That is why we need to create effective standards for the protection of citizens with disabilities and a functioning system for their active involvement in everyday life. It is also very important to promote simplification and better access for disabled people to new technologies. Assistance and participation of family, colleagues or employer is essential for the full integration of women and girls with disabilities into society. The basis for change is thus the actions of their closest people. In view of the forthcoming European elections, the European Commission's proactive approach towards disabled citizens is irreplaceable. So that women with disabilities can not only vote, but, above all, more easily compete for people's trust in elections.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. – All persons with disabilities must be able to fully benefit from their rights on the basis of inclusion and full participation in society. The social and economic participation of women with disabilities is essential to the success of Europe's overall economic and social strategy. They must be guaranteed full enjoyment of rights with regard to quality, accessible and affordable education, health care, including specific health care for transgender people and sexual and reproductive health and related rights, employment, mobility, family life, physical autonomy, sexuality and marriage, as well as safeguards guaranteeing those rights. I call on the Commission to present a proposal for a European Disability Strategy 2020-2030 that fully integrates the provisions of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities into EU future legislation, policies and programmes and that is consistent with the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and the Strategic Commitment to Gender Equality 2016-2019 , in order to ensure that women and girls with disabilities can enjoy their rights as well as any other person.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Women with disabilities, depending on age, place of residence, social status or, finally, type of disability, experience various difficulties related to their daily functioning. These are problems of two kinds: on the one hand, they concern obtaining a suitable education or finding a dream job, and on the other hand individual characteristics related to self-acceptance and self-esteem. In addition, communication and architectural barriers make simple activities very complicated or even impossible for them in everyday life.  I agree with the resolution's resolution on promoting initiatives to promote professional activation and ensure equal access to education and work. Otherwise, it may result in poverty and social exclusion. The removal of all barriers must be enforced and the social discrimination experienced by them must be combated. It is necessary to implement prevention, treatment, rehabilitation and integration policies for persons with disabilities and to provide support to their families.  I believe that when discussing people with disabilities, we should not introduce ideological differences into the debate. In my opinion, the resolution should be devoid of any world-view provisions, especially those relating to sexual orientation and abortion. The inclusion of these themes makes the resolution subject to ideological disputes and does not serve the disabled. Let us bear in mind that the issue of helping women with disabilities is close to the majority of MEPs, and the issue of the availability of abortion or gender reassignment is no longer the case.

name: Czesław HOC
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – It has been accepted that attitudes towards people with disabilities are a measure of today's civilization. The approach to disability has evolved from treating people with disabilities as charitable activities to seeing them as rights-gived. In the modern sense of disability, fully recognising the importance of humanity and the dignity of persons with disabilities, they are shown to have rights on an equal footing with others.  We can no longer look at people with disabilities through the lens of continuous care and assistance. Today, the disabled do not expect pity and super-privileges. They want to be treated in the light of human rights, as well as scientific advances in treatment, rehabilitation and education, which would guarantee equal opportunities and protection against discrimination. They want a sense of security and a solidarity attitude. First you need to see the person, then possibly his wheelchair. This is particularly true for women and girls with disabilities, who are three times more likely to be violent than able-bodied women. We urgently need to remove existing obstacles and barriers, including architectural barriers, in order to create equality of rights and opportunities for women and girls to participate in family, political, cultural, social and professional life.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. – The word 'disability' covers many different temporary, short-term or long-term personal situations that require tailored political responses and involve psychological difficulties. All persons with disabilities should be able to fully enjoy their rights on the basis of inclusion and participate fully in society.  This is only possible with the implementation of active and public policies and with the removal of all barriers to participation. Around 46 million women and girls with disabilities live in the EU today, accounting for around 16% of the total number of women in the Union and 60% of the total population with disabilities, and only 18.8% of women with disabilities in the EU are employed. Women and girls with disabilities are subjected to double discrimination due to a combination of sex and disability and can often be subjected to multiple discrimination arising from a combination of gender and disability.  This motion for a resolution calls on the Member States to implement policies for the prevention, treatment, rehabilitation and integration of persons with disabilities and to support their families and to take responsibility for the effective exercise of their rights, without prejudice to the rights and duties of parents or guardians.  It also calls for the development of pedagogy that makes society awareness of the duty of respect and solidarity for persons with disabilities in order to combat the social discrimination to which those persons are exposed.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. – In 2013, the EMPL Committee adopted the opinion on women with disabilities with 33 yeses and 6 abstentions, of which I was rapporteur. 5 years later, it is important to stress that all forms of discrimination on grounds of disability and gender should be prohibited. The group of women with disabilities is subject to greater exclusion and multiple discrimination. The European Social Fund should be used as an effective tool for greater involvement of women with disabilities in all important areas of life, such as free access to the labour market, training and (general) education. Women's inactivity rates are higher, they do less skilled work, they work with less responsibility and lower pay, they live in greater social isolation, they are more financially dependent on family and carers. As the population ages, the proportion of older people with disabilities increases, with more women due to their longer life expectancy. Greater attention should be paid to deaf people using sign language, especially the elderly with low hearing (their numbers and proportions are increasing within society). The UNION and the Member States should share examples of innovative design and cooperate in the field of standardisation. Confronting stereotypes can also be achieved through a real, inspiring example of women with disabilities, demonstrating how their abilities compensate for their disability and enable them to succeed in professional and family life.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. – There are more than 80 million people with disabilities in the EU, 60% of whom are women. One of the problems of an ageing society is also the increasing number of people with disabilities at a higher age. 45% of women with working age disabilities are not active in the labour market. The situation of women with disabilities who work compared to men – both in terms of income and social exclusion – has also deteriorated. Women are the guardian of 2/3 cases of disabled people; 80% of carers with disabilities are not paid; Seveny- and 75% of them are women.  In view of all of the above, more measures must be taken to improve the situation of people with disabilities, but especially women. Technological developments provide many opportunities to increase the involvement of people with disabilities in the labour market. All people with disabilities must be able to exercise their rights and be fully involved in society. Women with disabilities need to place greater emphasis on health and sexual and reproductive rights and to contribute to greater female independence. Concerns must also be acknowledged at political level and every action must be made to remove barriers to the full life of people with disabilities and to contribute to the promotion of their rights and opportunities in society.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: Written. – The purpose of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is to guarantee all human rights and fundamental freedoms to persons with disabilities in full and on an equal footing and to promote respect for their dignity.  The rights of people with disabilities do not come true by themselves, but require not only action from decision-makers, but also inclusion and active dialogue. The accessibility directive, on the other hand, aims to ensure that everyone has equal opportunities for action in society, including digital.  We are all entitled to the basic services we need. It is important to recognize the different needs of individuals, different people. It is also important to identify the different needs of women and men. In order to achieve equality, its conditions must be in order. For example, it is essential to extend non-discrimination beyond the workplace by adopting the Equal Treatment Directive, which is stuck in the treatment of Member States. The principles of gender equality and equal opportunities for women and men set out in the European Pillar of Social Rights must be implemented at a practical level.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. – Next week we will celebrate International Day of People with Disabilities. It is very important to remember these days – however, we should think about the fact that people with disabilities have the same rights as anyone else throughout the year. People with disabilities are often invisible to society, especially for women. I find it truly unacceptable that women with disabilities are employed in roughly half the number compared to men. We cannot therefore be surprised that they are most at risk of poverty and social exclusion. In addition to having lower incomes and pensions, they are also more likely than men to stay at home to care for other family members without pay. We need to change this practice. Women with disabilities must be able to participate fully in public life and apply for their rights. One of the basic ways to do this is to be able to vote and choose your representatives. I therefore hope that the next elections to the European Parliament, and not just those, will be fully accessible to all, including people with disabilities. I would also like to call on my colleagues to consult organisations representing people with disabilities in their legislative work and in the preparation of any proposals, because this is the only way we can ensure that their rights are actually taken into account.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Colleagues, I would like to say that we are pleased to welcome a delegation from Majlisi Oli, chaired by Sharif Rahimzoda, to the visitors' gallery today. The delegation is here in Brussels to participate in the seventh Parliamentary Cooperation Committee on the European Parliament-Tajikistan.  We are very pleased to host this important meeting which will strengthen our dialogue and cooperation. It is an honour to see you here, at the heart of European democracy, a sign of our common commitment to promoting human rights, political pluralism through the rule of law.  On behalf of the european Parliament as a whole, ladies and gentlemen, I wish you a fruitful meeting and a good stay in Europe.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to my colleagues that, in the  context of today’s historic address by two Nobel Peace laureates – one to another, because the EU itself won the Peace Prize in 2012 – I want to inform you that yesterday. 28 November, was the seventh anniversary of the Brussels Declaration – a Pledge to Peace, signed here in this House in the European Parliament under the patronage of Gianni Pittella, then First Vice—President. The pledge encourages projects and actions aimed at promoting peace in its most universal meaning, based on the significance of each individual person. It’s inspired by the universal ideas of human dignity, freedom, equality and solidarity enshrined in the preamble of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and confirmed by the Lisbon Treaty in 2009. So let’s remember, folks, that the European Union is, and always will be, a peace project. (Applause)

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls Voting Time. (For voting results and other details about them: see minutes)

name: Miriam DALLI
text: Mr. Rapporteur, i.e. – Fil-fatt, abbażi tal-Artikolu 59, paragrafu 4, nixtieq nitlob li din il-materja tiġi rreferuta lill-Kumitat biex inkunu nistgħu nagħtu bidu ganħ-negozjati interistituzzjonali.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I request that the matter be referred back to committee for interinstitutional negotiations, pursuant to Rule 59(4).

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: – Madam President, I have a point of order. I’d like to take my name off the resolution by the Committee on Petitions (PETI) on Jugendamt. The text that we have just voted is not the draft text that I proposed. It has been substantially changed by the vote in the committee, and therefore I’d like to take my name off the text. This is not my text and should not be recorded as such.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Ma'am, we're actually recording the removal of your name.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: – Frau Präsidentin! Wir hätten gerne einen mündlichen Änderungsantrag. Das heißt: Ziffer 21a: ‘Notes with concern that women living in rural and remote areas and Roma and Egyptian women continue to have limited access to primary health care and sexual and reproductive health services and are often unaware about the availability of such services, calls on the Albanian authorities to ensure better information about such services and ensure that they are accessible, affordable and of quality’.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: This closes the voting time.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – It is extremely important in this resolution to identify the country where there have been such serious problems with fraud: Germany. It is a very sad picture that such an important country in the European Union has allowed loopholes into such a serious scandal.  I would remind you that German law allowed fiskus to lose EUR 55 billion in the 11 Member States of the European Union. All this thanks to rogue bankers, lawyers, stock brokers. This is an amount that would certainly cover most of the needs of the German Bundeswehr. I will draw attention to the importance of this resolution in two elements, firstly in this concern about the possibility of bringing about such a gap, and the second: the call that was made by my colleague Darius Rosati, for which I wanted to thank very warmly and emphasise the importance of this call.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Madam President, the Cum-Ex scandal has once again demonstrated that where the authorities close their eyes, investigative journalists bring the truth to the surface. They discovered how 55 billion euros were stolen from honest people who pay their taxes. It took ten years for Germany to amend the legislation and prohibit the fraudulent return of dividend taxes. This problem also faces France and Denmark and the Netherlands and many other countries. However, the authorities stumble upon cumbersome, non-functioning collaboration procedures, and the result is that those who steal from us, the criminals, remain unpunished. How-Ex is the biggest scam in the history of Europe and shows us that a European response is needed, firmly, quickly, now, yesterday, to stop this theft of public money.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, the EU Member States have lost at least EUR 55 billion as a result of cum-ex dividends. This tax scandal, too, came to light thanks to the work of investigative journalists. Once again, the authorities have been sitting on the information and the information has not flowed as desired between the Member States.  The ex scandal also gives a good example of the problem of the revolving door phenomenon. Hanno Berger, the former head of the Frankfurt Tax Office, was hired on the banking world side to develop complex dividend-mic models. In Berger's view, even aggressive dividend washing has been legal. It is difficult to understand how, for example, arrangements where several people apply for the same tax refund, even if the tax has not been paid even once, may have been legal in some countries.   The scandal shows that much remains to be done in the area of tax avoidance and aggressive work against tax planning. As a result, it was easy to vote in favour of the resolution.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, the Cum-Ex tax fraud scheme, as has been mentioned, has cost EU countries a reported 55 billion: a huge sum of money. Through complex share deals with no economic purpose other than to receive tax reimbursements from the state and no actual tax being paid, European citizens have, to put it bluntly, been robbed. The EU has made significant progress in tackling money laundering and tax fraud. However, the Cum-Ex scandal has shown that there is still a gap in effective implementation, enforcement and administrative cooperation between Member States. This scandal has, naturally, caused outrage across Europe. Urgent coordinated action at EU level is needed. This kind of large-scale tax fraud needs to be clamped down on, and we must assess the strength of the laws we have in place to this end.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, you might say that once the scandal was unveiled, the system worked. Investigative journalists did their job, legislation was changed. I’m struggling to understand why the rest of us are now piling in to opine on what is essentially a German domestic matter. Germany is not a failed state; on the contrary, it’s a country whose rule of law is beyond question and whose authorities operate according to impartial rules. A little bit of me wonders whether this isn’t part of this Chamber’s constant obsession with trying to have a common fiscal policy, which would really be about reducing competition rather than about cracking down on avoidance. But I have to say – perhaps I’m the only person in the House who feels this – isn’t it slightly odd to hear all of these outraged squeals about tax avoidance from Members of the European Parliament, who are exempt from paying national income tax?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, I voted in favour of the report because the German social care service for children and young people, the famous 'Jugendamt', has really crossed the line with its action over the years. There are countless complaints made to the Committee on Petitions. Parents complain, especially those who are established in Germany and are not German citizens, but are Greek, French, Croats. We have repeatedly received too many complaints from Poles as well. Jugendamt follows the following logic: if one of the parents is German, she always supports him; he always supports the Germans. And this is now an administrative practice that has been in place for years. Jugendamt intervenes in the functioning of family law in a discreet manner to the detriment of those who are not Germans.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The activities of the German Jugendamts have been objectionable for years, and very often we have had to talk unsuccessfully about respecting the rights of every parent, especially in cases of broken families. It is good that this subject, albeit late, was finally taken up by the European Parliament.  We must always remember that human rights first concern faith, family, education, human dignity, national identity. The rights of power-fighting politicians are only a derivative. And it is good that we are talking about this clearly in this resolution today. I hope that the result will be greater openness to criticism of the liberal state, the awareness that social engineering cannot destroy the most elementary human rights and that people, simply people, will be safer.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: – I voted in favour of the report, which draws attention to discrimination against parents by the German Jugendamt, which, called to care for the welfare of children, actually acts against them by taking children away from their parents, especially foreigners. Discrimination against parents who are not of German nationality, taking away children for trivial reasons, also applies to the Netherlands and other countries where article 24 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights is violated, where it is written that every child has the right to maintain a permanent personal relationship and direct contact with both parents, unless this is contrary to his or her interests. In petitions to the Commission, there is numerous evidence of violations of the rights of the child, identity, freedom, personal security and a ban on communication in the mother tongue, subsequent Germanisation, which leads to the breakdown of the family and is the cause of great trauma for children, orphan disease and even the death of children separated from their mothers. The Jugendamt, which receives huge child benefits of several thousand euros, enters virtually every sphere of life.

name: Czesław HOC
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I voted in favour of the resolution on the Jugendamtu, because this subject causes a lot of controversy, opposition and emotion, as evidenced by the huge number of petitions that are submitted to the European Parliament. This issue must be looked at primarily from the perspective of genuine human dramas, particularly children's dramas, and not from the point of view of so-called political correctness.  According to information provided by the Polish Association of Parents Against Discrimination against Child Discrimination in Germany, in 2016 alone the Jugendamt took away 77 000 children from families, of which at least 20 000 are Polish children. Parents often have no contact with their children for years, and during supervised visits they cannot communicate with them in their mother tongue.  Let us remember that a few years ago the Committee on Petitions of the European Parliament also adopted a critical report on the Jugendamt, but there was no positive reaction, reflection on improvement or empathy on the part of the Jugendamts. It is therefore high time that the German Child and Adolescent Authorities started to act only in the interests of the best interests of the child and in strengthening the potential of the biological family.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, dar ndóigh tá obair an-mhaith á déanamh ag Coiste PETI, agus thug mé féin cúpla agóid ós a chomhair agus thug siad moladh an-mhaith faoi na hagóidí sin.  Ach sa chás seo, cé go nglacaim go hiomlán gur cheart do thuismitheoirí go háirithe a bheith in ann cumarsáid a dhéanamh lena mic agus lena gclann ina dteanga dhúchais féin, ag an am céanna vótáil mise agus mo ghrúpa i gcoinne na tuarascála, mar dáiríre baineann sé seo le tír amháin agus tá sé de dhualgas ar an tír sin é a réiteach.   Freisin, fuair Coiste PETI agóidí ó thrí thír eile, dá bhrí sin, ba chóir dúinn féachaint orthu go léir le chéile gan díriú ar thír amháin.  Fós féin, aontaím go hiomlán leis an bprionsabal atá anseo.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, this is an area where we have to tread very sensitively. We’re talking about the most intimate and important matters: relations between parents and children. I’ve come across a number of heart-breaking cases both on the Petitions Committee and indeed as constituency cases in the UK, and yet I have to come down on the same side as my EPP friend Sean Kelly. This is fundamentally – precisely because of its sensitive nature – the sort of issue that should be determined by each country through its national democratic mechanisms and procedures. For the second time in a row I find myself rising in defence of German sovereignty. That’s not to say that there isn’t a problem. But the people to sort that problem out are those most directly involved, namely the authorities of the Member State in question.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Madam President, the multilateral rules—based system is under threat as never before. It is our collective responsibility to uphold it in these trying times, especially under the attack of the current US President. In a world of raw power politics, neither the EU nor any of its Member States, individually, stands a chance of promoting a progressive future.  The keystone of the global order is the WTO. It is to date the most advanced of all the multilateral institutions. Its dispute settlement mechanism is one of the very few instruments at international level with the power to resolve conflicts peacefully. In the past, we know as a continent that economic conflicts often lead to military conflicts. But the WTO is far from perfect. It’s high time we broadened its scope to make it a real instrument for development, workers and the environment.  So to save the WTO we must make it more efficient and accountable, and that’s why I supported the report today.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The source of yesterday's debate as well as the report itself is extremely important. Let me remind you that this is a failure, but it is a failure that started in 2008, when the first resolution in support of the need for a review of the WTO was adopted. Why? Because they're stuck.  For me, it is very important that from this year 2008 to 2018, not so much nothing was done, but not much was done. I would remind you that, after the last WTO ministerial conference in Buenos Aires in December, exactly last year, it became apparent that the negotiating function of the organisation had been completely paralysed. This has become an even more urgent task, and hence our debate. Once again, it cannot be said that little or nothing has been done in the last 10 years. A lot has been done, but this is completely insufficient for the smooth functioning of this institution.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Madam President, commercial property values plunging by almost half, house prices down 30%, sterling down by 25%, living standards hit, GDP down 8% on what was forecast – just some of this week’s forecasts on the hits the UK economy would take in the event of a no—deal Brexit. We heard earlier in this House some advocating a no—deal Brexit and trade purely and only on WTO rules. Those who advocate that position never seem to be able to answer the most obvious question: that if WTO rules are so perfect, why do countries spend so much time and energy to secure FTAs over and above WTO arrangements? Those advocating a hard deal / no—deal Brexit today must answer the question, why do they want to see people across the UK made poorer? Talk of a no—deal Brexit must be dismissed today for what it is, which is dangerous, preposterous nonsense.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Madam President, I welcome this report into how we make the WTO more relevant. WTO rules are, for the first time in my memory, being talked about in everyday conversation in Britain. The hard—line Brexiteers tell us a no—deal Brexit is simply about adopting WTO rules. But what would that mean in practice for British businesses that export to Europe? An end to zero tariffs, a big change from today. It would result in a 12% tariff to export the fish that we capture around Suffolk shores and in Luton van parts will be taxed at 10% every time they cross the border between the UK and the EU and a 21% tariff to sell the tomatoes grown in Essex into Europe. Plus, unlike today, there will be quotas limiting the amount that we could sell into the EU and that’s before we even start to think about renegotiating and starting the 124 new trade agreements currently handled through the EU with the rest of the world. President, it seems to me that our proud exporting nation would be decimated.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, the WTO remains an example of a rules—based multilateral institution that brings a certain degree of order into the house of post—modern states. It is a precious platform for the EU to promote the values of multilateralism. However, it is becoming even more difficult considering the free—riding behaviour of some states, like the USA.  I am glad to see that the report calls for the eradication of poverty and removing barriers to women’s participation in trade. I believe that our task is to make commerce as inclusive as possible. I also welcome the fact that the report calls for more transparency in international trade as a way to increase stability.  My special attention goes to the provisions on developing countries. I believe that both these and the EU, in compliance with WTO principles, should avoid a situation of donor—charity—receiver. To allow our partners to grow we need to treat them as equals and demand the same level of trade compliance from developing countries as from our developed countries.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I welcome the approval drafted by Mr Lange and Mr Rübig regarding the modernisation of the World Trade Organization and the way in which it operates. I welcome this report, as I believe this change is essential in order to make the WTO more relevant and adaptive to a changing, more globalised world, while strengthening the effectiveness of the organisation itself. I believe this legislation will help to overcome the difficulties and the failure of the Ministerial Conference held in Buenos Aires last December and deliver on some of the issues of the DDA. This legislation, if passed, will address the current gaps in the rule book, which create an uneven playing field in regards to subsidies and state—owned enterprises as well as regulatory barriers to services and investments. This legislation also looks at creating the necessary framework to cope with technological developments, including e-commerce, global value change and SMEs. A Uachtaráin, is jab maith é, comhghairdeas le Lange agus Rübig.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, to consider the miracle – the power – of free trade, consider the story of Hong Kong. After the Second World War its GDP was a third of that of the UK. By 1997 it had drawn level; now it’s 30% higher. Based on what? What natural resources does that island have? It has to import its drinking water, its food, its electricity – it is utterly reliant on things it brings in from elsewhere. Its magic was simply to remove all obstacles to trade and not to make it contingent on what any other country did. There was a unilateral removal of tariff and non-tariff barriers that led to this extraordinary flowering of prosperity. Similar thing in Singapore: went from half of our level of wealth in the 1950s to twice what it is today. And Britain outside the customs union as a WTO member will have the opportunity to do something similar to return to what first raised us above the run of nations in the 19th century, which is to remove barriers between businesses and their customers. That’s all you need to do; the magic follows.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I want to agree with my speaker that economists really agree that removing all barriers is the most important thing for trade, but unfortunately this is not how international politics and relations between states work. An important role is really played by this organization, which is trying to bring order to business relations and, in fact, to the resolution of trade disputes, but lately we have been pursuing a kind of paralysis of this organization, at least for more than 10 years, and these trade disputes are increasing. China has joined this organization, but it does not aming into the ideas or spirit of the organization. In principle, we are also on the cusp of a trade war because of the Trump administration's contradictory measures, so it is important that Europe takes on an active role, which is why I supported this resolution, because it really provides for stability, transparency in this organisation, rules for developing countries or rules for new technologies. All this is needed, Europe must be active. Let's do this.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would remind you that Serbia started official negotiations in 2014. Since then, we have 35 chapters, out of this open 14, which is not even half. Only 2 have been closed. I would like to draw attention to this fact because, at this rate, the prospect of Serbia's membership of the European Union is 40 or even 50 years, if, of course, this pace is maintained.  It is extremely important to me that the report on this issue itself is very good and has been positively assessed, while Serbia's progress in implementing those elements to which it has committed itself is unfortunately unsatisfactory. I would like to emphasise, in particular, that of these 35 chapters, the greatest shortcomings or lack of progress have been noted primarily in the area of the rule of law and freedom of expression. I would remind you that these issues have been considered extremely important.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, Serbia is a proud country with a long, rich history. The modern history is quite rapid. From the disintegration of the state, the war, to the hiding of some war criminals, I want to appreciate the progress, even if it is really small, on the side of this country that it has made, and I assume that it is really heading for that democratic community of Europe. But it is important that this country fulfils the roles it has set out to do. It is a fact that it is important for the Czech Republic and I think that it is important for the whole of Europe that we can really give hope to the Balkan countries. However, some countries in the Balkans have done much more, we will talk about this perhaps at the following point.  A peaceful future and cooperation, economic prosperity, if Serbia is really seeking them, I think it must work. The report really describes it, I think credibly, and I supported it. However, I am showing that Serbia, if it is serious, should also work more.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Kosovo receives invaluable advice from the European Union on how to fight terrorism. The European Union recommends that terrorists be rehabilitated, subjected to education and social inclusion. Well, really, I can already see the terrorists bending down now out of fear of their knees and the terrorist father tells his son, watch out, because if they get caught, then you will be subjected in the European Union to such education, rehabilitation and integration that you will truly regret it.  Dear people, terrorism is being fought by the reintroduction of the death penalty. What you say, this education, rehabilitation and integration, is reward, not punishment. Education needs to be earned, integration must be earned, and you want to give it to people for free in the name of fighting terrorism for being terrorists. It is God's arms of Kosovo against advisers such as the European Union.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I supported the report on Macedonia because it has made considerable progress towards possible accession to the EU. Among the candidate states, one of the most advanced, although problems remain with the democratic nature of politics, respect for the rule of law, including the problems of corruption and the inclusion of minorities. That is why it is also receiving a substantial contribution from the EU to implement reforms. It is very positive that an agreement has been found between Macedonia and Greece on the name of the country, which has already been approved by the Macedonian Parliament. The report also mentions that former Prime Minister Gruevski fled Macedonia to Hungary, where he is seeking asylum. I assume that the former Prime Minister will be extradited to Macedonia, where he should appear as a final sentence, so he will be extradited.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, Skopje continues to take over the name of our Macedonia and our history. At the same time, even with the new Constitution they have adopted, they continue their unsymonic policy, as Article 36 continues to refer to so-called 'Macedonia' and so-called 'Macedonian people'. At the same time, in the preamble to the Constitution, they refer to the 1944 ASNOM decision, which explicitly states that there is a right of self-determination of the so-called "Macedonian nation" and self-determination of the so-called "Macedonian people". Therefore, even this despicable agreement of the Prespas is violated by the Macedonians, and therefore the agreement of the Prespas is dead and the Greek government is not even entitled to submit it to the Greek parliament. I am therefore opposed to any future accession of Skopje to the European Union and, of course, I voted against this report.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In the report voted on, Parliament commends the considerable efforts made by Macedonia and Greece to find a mutually accepted solution to the issue of the name of the country. Macedonia, however, faces similar problems as other countries in the region. In paragraph 32, we call on the authorities to take action to break up criminal networks involved in trafficking in human beings, weapons and drugs.  As with Albania and Montenegro, the report on Macedonia shows excessive concern for LGBTI people. In paragraph 43, the following paragraph shall be added: Parliament is calling for punishment for homophobic and transphobic violence, while it welcomes the establishment of a cross-party parliamentary circle on the rights of the LGBTI community. I consider these provisions to be superfluous, which is why I voted against this report.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Madam President, as a member of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of this House and that of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, I am pleased to support this report. There’s clearly much work yet to be done before Macedonia can accede to this Union, but it should be clear to anyone whose eyes are open that significant progress has been made. Settling disputes like the name dispute between Macedonia and Greece requires politicians of courage, who are prepared to tell the truth to the people that they seek to lead. The simple truth here is that the Prespa Agreement might not be perfect but nobody – not the nationalists in Macedonia nor the nationalists in this place – have suggested any alternative to the Prespa Agreement other than stagnation and stalemate. So let’s praise the courage of those members of the Sobranie who supported the constitutional changes and look forward to progress on media freedom, and political and civil administration.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, Macedonia has had candidate status since 2005 and has indeed made very significant progress since then. After all, the amendment to the Constitution to be made under the Prespy Agreement, on the basis of that vote of 19 October, is indeed a huge piece of work that has been done. The nationalists offer no other solution. I want to appreciate this effort. I want to support those currents that are moving towards reconciliation between the two states, and I think that if someone is changing the constitution because of that, I think that demonstrates that effort.  However, much needs to be done to the country's past, e.g. the report mentions the issue of a special prosecutor to investigate past crimes. I mean criminal offences, I think that's an important task that Macedonia will have to do, but I think that's a good way to go.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, I have repeatedly stated here in this House that I am opposed to any future accession of Albania to the European Union. All the more so as the oppression of the Greek ethnic minority of northern Epirus continues. We recently had, a month ago, the murder of Konstantinos Katsifas by the Albanian police. Albania continues, therefore, to seize the property of the Greeks, to tear down the churches, to alter the population in the North Continent and, at the moment, to retaliate again. It cuts the tide and intimidates all Greeks in the North Continent, all to get the message across that it will supposedly continue its policy; the politics of oppression. We tell her, therefore, that this is not going through and that we will constantly denounce it - here in the European Parliament - until she recognises and implements the rights of the Greek ethnic minority in the North Continent. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In the report voted on, the Commission recommends opening accession negotiations with Albania. They are intended, as highlighted in the document, to allow for closer scrutiny by the Union and for reforms to be carried out. As in other candidate countries, we draw attention to the repeated dangerous trend of trafficking in human beings. This is mentioned in paragraph 18, where our Parliament calls on the Albanian authorities to take decisive action to break up criminal networks involved in trafficking in human beings, as well as firearms and drugs. Unnecessarily, however, section 23 specifically promotes gender ideology by including LGBTI provisions. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, Albania has made significant progress, and this needs to be acknowledged and rewarded. That’s why I very much like the idea of supporting the accession negotiations with Albania next year. While being aware of the progress that has been made, especially in the juridical reform, we have as well to point out the things that still remain to be done. The electoral reforms remain a concern. The issues of corruption, organised crime and good neighbourhood relations – the reforms in these areas are painful, but they have to be done; they are essential. The rule of law, respect for human rights and the fight against corruption have to be improved. With this goal, we should all ensure the opening of the negotiations and avoiding further backsliding.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I wanted to refer to the scandalous situation in which an oral amendment is tabled in plenary, which is not merely a spelling correction, but a littering of EU documents with some sexist tales about women in the countryside, who need something – at the expense of other taxpayers, of course – to provide. Such a formula should be critically assessed, as should the scandalous content of the amendment itself. Furthermore, I regret to say that there were not forty fair Members who would have opposed this amendment during the session. Only a few Members have come up to oppose this. It is really sad and pathetic that you are afraid to come forward in such an obvious matter.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I would like to explain why I supported the report on Montenegro, which is seeking accession to the EU. I consider it to be a country that shares our European roots and therefore seeks to join the EU, as demonstrated by its efforts to meet the Copenhagen criteria. The report states that Montenegro has made progress in negotiations with the EU, particularly in its domestic policy. There has been an improvement in the state of independence of the courts, e-government. Another positive indicator was the recent presidential elections in April this year, when no serious violations were detected on the issue of citizens' free decision-making. We have some concerns about media freedom and, of course, here, as an EP, we will be following developments.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I voted against this report. Last night I spoke on this subject. I would like to draw attention to some of the iunctim linking the reports on Macedonia and Albania. Here, too, in its report on Montenegro in paragraph 22, Parliament regrets the lack of progress in combating trafficking in human beings. This is repeated in every report. There, people are traffickered, and here it is further indicated that children are being forced to beg.  I said yesterday that this is disgraceful and no country aspiring to join the European Union should tolerate it, but there is also a second trend where our Parliament cares too much about so-called minorities. In paragraph 34, we write that we are concerned about the difficulties in accepting sexual diversity in Montenegrin society. I consider these provisions to be superfluous. That is why, I repeat, I voted against this report.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, I thank Mr Tannock for his excellent and detailed report. Montenegro remains a frontrunner in the Western Balkans, with Chapter 31 open, and we would like the process to continue on that path. However, certain things have to be pointed out, like the fact that media freedom remains an issue in that country.
